article text: Businessman Femi Otedola and his wife Nana Otedola have hosted their daughter Florence aka DJ Cuppy and her fianc√© Ryan Taylor at their residence.  DJ Cuppy unveiled her fianc√© on social media last year. She said she got engaged to him just two days after they met.  The disc jockey shared photos of their visit on Instagram Story on Saturday.  In one of the photos, she dressed in matching outfits with her mum.  Taylor, a British boxer, took selfies with his future father-in-law.  DJ Cuppy, Taylor, Otedola and Nana also posed for photos together.  Taylor and fianc√©e have yet to announce their wedding date.

Sign up for the Hot Topics newsletter for hot style and sex tips  Two women who made a name for themselves as Hugh Hefner‚Äôs favourite Playboy Bunnies have been feuding for years.  Since the Playboy Mansion closed its doors a number of years ago, we have learnt that life inside wasn‚Äôt as glamorous as we were made to think it was.  Former Playmates have shared tales of carpets encrusted with dog excrement, unhygienic-sounding group-pleasure sessions and shady methods of payment.  READ MORE: 'You don't need to be pretty to be a sex worker ‚Äì you have to be smart'  While Holly Madison and Kendra Wilkinson were regularly photographed together and seemed to get along, they‚Äôre no longer talking.  Holly began dating Hugh in 2001 after she attended one of the weekly pool parties at the mansion and Kendra started dating the magazine publisher after she worked his 78th birthday party in 2004.  When E! cameras were allowed inside the wrought iron gates to film the series for The Girls Next Door, the group ‚Äì which also included Bridget Marquardt ‚Äì became recognised as more than just Hugh's girlfriends.  (Image: WireImage)  Holly, Kendra and Bridget were the stars of the reality series, which premiered in August 2005 and ran for five seasons.  But while they seemed to get along during and after the filming of Girls Next Door, their relationship quickly fell apart.  Even though Holly and Bridget were Kendra‚Äôs bridesmaids when she walked down the aisle in 2009, during a 2012 interview with CNN, Kendra said she was ‚Äúnever even really friends‚Äù with the pair.  And this isn‚Äôt the only time she‚Äôs spoken out about her relationship with the former Playmates.  ‚ÄúAt the end of the day, it‚Äôs a very awkward situation ‚Äôcause it‚Äôs not like we‚Äôre The Spice Girls,‚Äù Kendra said on Fox 5‚Äôs Good Day New York in 2015.  (Image: Getty Images for Leather & Laces) (Image: Gamma-Rapho via Getty Images)  ‚ÄúWe dated an 80-year-old man at the same time. It‚Äôs very awkward. [Holly] probably wants to distance herself from that situation. God bless her, she should. It‚Äôs embarrassing because I saw some things that she probably doesn‚Äôt want me to talk about.‚Äù  In the same year, Holly alleged in her 2015 memoir Down the Rabbit Hole that despite appearances, she and Kendra‚Äôs relationship was rocky from the start.  "Hungry from her own 'team,' Kendra desperately tried to make each new Playmate who arrived at the Mansion her friend ‚Äî and her friend alone,‚Äù she wrote.  ‚ÄúAt 19 years old, Kendra was stuck with a 9PM curfew, a 78-year-old boyfriend, and a stricter set of rules than she had ever had at home.  ‚ÄúAnd now, adding insult to injury, she was finally realising that she wasn‚Äôt as special as Hef made her believe. She was just another blonde girlfriend ‚Äì and life at the Mansion wasn‚Äôt all she imagined it to be.‚Äù  (Image: Getty Images North America)  The drama didn't end there ‚Äì as it seemed Holly felt betrayed after hearing Kendra thought they weren‚Äôt friends.  She addressed it in her memoir, revealing that she ended up texting Kendra to address how she really felt, calling her a "coward" and "the fakest person [she'd] ever met".  Holly concluded: ‚ÄúAfter that, I deleted her number from my phone. Kendra and I haven't spoken since, and I have to say, I don't miss her."  In an interview with Us Weekly at the time, Kendra slammed the book, saying ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame that someone can‚Äôt be appreciative of what something like that has given them.‚Äù  Over the years Holly and Kendra have continued to have a back-and-forth over how they feel about their time in the Mansion and what they think of each other.  (Image: FilmMagic)  The last time either of them addressed their fallout was in 2022 when Holly appeared on the Juicy Scoop podcast.  She said that originally, she ‚Äúloved Kendra" and felt like the pair had a sibling rivalry while in the Mansion.  But when Kendra was filming her reality show Kendra on Top in 2015, things apparently shifted.  ‚ÄúThings got weird with me and Kendra and I felt like [the producer] was encouraging that, like, he wanted us fighting, he wanted the drama," she said.  ‚ÄúHe wanted me to come on her show and, like, brag about how much money I was making in Vegas, so she'd get a little poke in the a** to take more jobs to make her show more interesting."  Yikes, sounds like there's no love lost there then...  READ NEXT:

Just two weeks ago today, Prince Harry was in the U.K., attending the Coronation ceremony of his father, King Charles. While relations seemingly remain icy between Harry and some members of the royal family (here‚Äôs looking at the Prince and Princess of Wales), anyone who watched coverage of the Coronation could see that Harry was clearly getting on with many members of his family. Even so, according to multiple outlets, Harry and wife Meghan Markle haven‚Äôt heard from the royal family since news broke of their ‚Äúnear catastrophic car chase‚Äù involving paparazzi earlier this week in New York City.  People reports that ‚Äúthe royal family has not reached out to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex since the incident occurred on Tuesday night.‚Äù (Adding fuel to this fire, the couple‚Äôs fifth wedding anniversary was yesterday, so there apparently has been no acknowledgement of that, either.) The Telegraph reports that Harry and Meghan are ‚Äúfrustrated‚Äù by ‚Äúthe lack of personal contact‚Äù from his family, with the outlet reporting ‚ÄúThe lack of personal contact, as well as Buckingham Palace‚Äôs refusal to publicly acknowledge or comment on the incident, is understood to have frustrated the couple, who friends suggested may have hoped to garner more support, particularly on a personal level.‚Äù  (Image credit: Getty)  (Image credit: Getty)  The incident occurred after Meghan was honored at the Ms. Foundation‚Äôs Women of Vision Awards in Manhattan Tuesday night; she brought Harry and mother Doria Ragland along as special guests. The chase, according to a Sussex spokesperson, lasted two hours and, according to a source speaking to People, left the couple ‚Äúshaken‚Äù: ‚ÄúIt was a disturbing situation, and they were shaken, but they are glad everyone‚Äôs okay,‚Äù the source says.  (Image credit: Getty)

Selling Sunset season 6 premiered on Friday, May 19, and featured Jason Oppenheim introducing his new girlfriend Marie-Lou Nurk. In addition to the new season‚Äôs excitement, fans were also surprised by an Instagram post that featured the couple in a white and black ensemble. Online users assumed that the two got married or engaged and stated that he had a wedding because his ex Chrishell Stause got married.  Fans react to Jason Oppenheim and Marie-Lou Nurk's recent online post (Image via marielounurk/Instagram)  However, Jason debunked the wedding rumors by responding to Marie-Lou‚Äôs Instagram post. He wrote:  ‚ÄúClearly these photos are confusing people. Sorry about that. We did not get married.‚Äù  He added that the photos were from an event the couple attended a few days ago.  Netizens pointed out that Selling Sunset newbie Marie-Lou Nurk changed the caption after wedding speculations  On Friday, Selling Sunset‚Äôs newest guest Marie-Lou Nurk shared an Instagram post, featuring her and Jason Oppenheim‚Äôs photos.  In the first picture, the two were seen running while holding hands. Marie-Lou donned a white feathered mini dress and Jason wore a black suit with a white shirt. The photos and her caption left netizens wondering whether the two got married.  Marie-Lou‚Äôs initial caption read:  ‚ÄúHere's to a lifetime of adventures.‚Äù  As the wedding speculations filled the comment section, she changed the caption to, "You always make me smile."  Just below the caption, Jason commented, stating that the photos were confusing people and that they were not married.  Netizens who assumed they were married took to the post's comments section to write down their reactions. While some responded sarcastically, others noted that the two changed the caption very quickly.  Fans react to Jason Oppenheim and Marie-Lou Nurk's recent online post (Image via marielounurk/Instagram)  Fans react to Jason Oppenheim and Marie-Lou Nurk's recent online post (Image via marielounurk/Instagram)  In the recently premiered Selling Sunset season 6, Jason introduced her model girlfriend Marie-Lou to the Oppenheim Group employees. While the ladies initially thought the new girl in Jason‚Äôs life was just a fling, he admitted to ex-lover Chrishell Stause that he was serious about Marie-Lou.  Selling Sunset cast pulled Jason‚Äôs leg over the age gap between him and Marie-Lou  The news of Jason Oppenheim dating a younger model came out in the open months before the premiere of Selling Sunset season 6. In episode 3, he brought in Marie-Lou to the Oppenheim office to introduce her to his colleagues.  Interestingly, the cast included three ladies whom Jason had dated in the past. He and Nicole Young were in a relationship 13 or 14 years ago, while he dated Mary Fitzgerald before she met her husband Romain. The latest was him and Chrishell Stause, as they were in a relationship in season 5.  When Jason brought in Marie-Lou into the office, Selling Sunset cast members started pulling his legs. Chelsea Lazkani started the age gap conversation by asking the model her age. Marie-Lou said 24 and then corrected it to 25 as it was her birthday. Chelsea further pulled Jason's leg by asking his age. In response, he said he is 45.  Once the couple left, the ladies made fun of their age gap. Throughout the season, the fun banters about their age were featured. In episode 7, Jason confessed to Chrishell that he was serious about his new girlfriend.  The ex-couple went out for dinner, when Chrishell spoke about G-Flip ‚Äînow married, the two were dating at the time. Chrishell stated that she and G were ready to adopt a baby and Jason could babysit from time to time. In response, he quipped that he and Lou would do it together.  Chrishell Stause replied:  ‚ÄúLou? She‚Äôs not gonna be around by the time I adopt someone.‚Äù  Looking at Jason‚Äôs expression, Chrishell was surprised to learn that he was serious about Lou.  Viewers can stream Selling Sunset season 6 on Netflix.  Poll : 0 votes

Ideas and people ‚Äújust turn up‚Äù in our lives when we need them, Evelyn Woodard believes.  Evelyn is one half of the husband-and-wife photography team of Keith and Evelyn Woodard.  First Light Carrantuohill, from The Woodard Collection.  We‚Äôre looking out windows as we speak, in Co Kerry, at mountains that the pair have immortalised on walls globally, thanks to interior designers snapping up The Woodard Collection for homes and corporate spaces alike.  Because in the past month, Evelyn and Keith have channelled their two decades together as high-profile wedding snappers into a whole new energy flow as in-demand interiors artists.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been passionate about interiors ‚Äî at one point we had nine couches in the house,‚Äù says Evelyn.  ‚ÄúBut as photographers, both Keith and I have a good eye naturally, and know what works.‚Äù  Keith and Evelyn Woodard.  ENTRY SPACE  Back to the notion of ‚Äújust turning up‚Äù.  The scene for Evelyn and Keith‚Äôs life ‚Äî and ultimately work ‚Äî partnership, was set in 1996.  That was when the pair first spotted one another in Evelyn‚Äôs local post office, in Faha, just outside Killarney, Co Kerry.  Then, he was a 35-year-old father of three, newly separated from his wife.  Evelyn was 22 and both were immediately smitten, but initially thought the other was married.  ‚ÄúKeith had moved into the area and had been living here with his three kids when I met him,‚Äù says Evelyn. ‚ÄúHe was so tanned I thought he might be Italian ‚Äî until he opened his mouth to speak! I was so disappointed to discover he was only from the UK,‚Äù she jokes.  The Dingle Train from The Woodard Collection.  Prior to becoming a photographer, London-born Keith had played tournaments throughout Europe as a professional golfer, with the likes of Nick Faldo.  Keith had come to Ireland on a golfing holiday in 1984. He married an Irish woman and was manager of Ballybunion Golf Club.  It was his golfing career that led to Keith‚Äôs photography career, which developed into a successful wedding photography business. ‚ÄúKeith literally started out by taking photographs of golf courses,‚Äù says Evelyn.  MARRIAGE SPACES  Evelyn ‚Äî who formerly worked in business and corporate travel ‚Äî and Keith themselves exchanged vows in Baltimore, Co Cork, in 2003. They have a son, Marc, 21, and Keith‚Äôs sons and daughters ‚Äî Nick, Jason, and Siran ‚Äî from his previous marriage.  One day, Keith asked Evelyn to help him out at a wedding. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how I got into photography,‚Äù she says.  Evelyn Woodard.  The bride and groom chose many of Evelyn‚Äôs shots, and the rest is history. High-profile nuptials they covered together over the years included the wedding of Michael Flatley and Niamh O‚ÄôBrien.  Keith Woodard.  OUTDOOR SPACES  Evelyn is quick to point out that Keith has helped her hone her photography skills. ‚ÄúI had never considered myself artistic at all, but even when Keith would photograph golf courses, I would walk the golf courses with him,‚Äù she says.  The Woodard Collection demonstrates how the couple‚Äôs work together is ‚Äúevolving‚Äù, she adds. ‚ÄúThe collection shows how we approach work from different angles,‚Äù says Evelyn.  Travel is another passion they share. ‚ÄúWe love Italy, France, and Lanzarote ‚Äî they‚Äôre our favourite countries,‚Äù says Evelyn. ‚ÄúKeith‚Äôs daughter Siran has lived in Lanzarote for the past 10 years, and we were recently there for her wedding ‚Äî but we just consider all of the west coast of Ireland as the most beautiful place in the world.‚Äù  The Way She Moves from The Woodard Collection.  INDOOR SPACES  The Woodard Collection includes not only a gallery of their photography of landscapes and seascapes, but also offers a bespoke service including room mock-ups to clients worldwide. ‚ÄúI definitely like to visualise what something will look like when I‚Äôm designing a space and I think a lot of people ‚Äî particularly women ‚Äî are the same,‚Äù says Evelyn.  HEALING SPACES  Photography is also healing, both as a pursuit and as an element of our spaces, I suggest. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing like it,‚Äù agrees Evelyn. ‚ÄúEspecially with our abstract works. We want to evoke a feeling of taking someone back to a time or place. If you‚Äôre stuck in an office, it‚Äôs wonderful to have something that transports you.‚Äù  A particularly healing image for Evelyn is the sea.  A piece from collection in a modern dining room.  Evelyn was diagnosed with breast cancer in July 2015. Following treatment, she recovered ‚Äúeight years ago now, and all is good‚Äù, she says. ‚ÄúThe sea is so healing and such a healing symbol, I find. When I was sick, I felt there was nothing in the world like it ‚Äî to be outside, near the water.‚Äù  The photographer is a fan of ‚Äúslow living‚Äù principles: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a worldwide movement but I feel since the pandemic we‚Äôre paying more attention to it in Ireland. We need to take stock. We can‚Äôt just say ‚Äòyes‚Äô to everything. Things just turn up. Things figure themselves out. Priorities change.‚Äù

If you're looking for an unforgettable bikini and swimsuit collection, the Southern Charm-er has one.  Look Back at Some of Madison LeCroy's Best Bikinis and Swimsuits  It‚Äôs safe to say that Madison LeCroy loves a sizzling swimsuit look. The Southern Charm-er routinely flaunts teeny bikinis and sexy one-pieces on social media ‚Äî and she even has a swimsuit collection with Beach Riot.  How to Watch Catch up on Southern Charm on Peacock or the Bravo App.  Whether she‚Äôs doing yard work at her Charleston abode or soaking up the sun in the Bahamas, Madison has the perfect swimsuit for every occasion, and she always makes sure to document the evidence. A tiny checkered bikini? Check. A sporty racerback one-piece? Also check. A floral embellished white two-piece inspired by her own wedding dress? Yes, that too.  If you‚Äôre looking for a bit of summer style inspiration, scroll down to relive all of Madison‚Äôs most scorching swim looks.  A pastel monokini fit for yard work  Even when she‚Äôs watering the plants on her front porch, Madison serves up fierce swim style. In a May 2023 Instagram post, she shared a look at her gardening attire: an abstract pastel-colored monokini. She topped the look with light pink sunglasses and added a couple of gold bangles for good measure. She quipped in her caption: ‚ÄúIn a world of pansies.‚Äù  A ‚Äúcute and sporty‚Äù racerback swimsuit  Photo: Madison LeCroy/Instagram  Related  Madison is very into fitness, and sometimes her swimsuits take on a similar athletic vibe. In a March 2023 Instagram Story, the mom showed off a sporty sky-blue racerback swimsuit with white trim.  She dubbed the look ‚Äúcute,‚Äù and we have to agree! (She also revealed the $32 bathing suit was from Target.)  A wedding dress-inspired bikini  Photo: Madison LeCroy/Instagram  When Madison walked down the aisle in November 2022, she stunned in a floral embellished Reem Acra gown with a sweetheart neckline and capped sleeves. Madison loved the look so much, she designed a swimsuit with Beach Riot inspired by her wedding dress.  Related  She revealed the two piece ‚Äî consisting of the Madison Top Ivory ($258) and LeCroy Bottom Ivory ($158) ‚Äî in a January 2023 Instagram Story.  ‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄúWe replicated my wedding dress with this, which I think is super fun if you‚Äôre, you know, going to, like, a beach bar, you can throw this on and look pretty dressy,‚Äù she shared in the Story. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very flattering in the top area and, as you can see, the back.‚Äù  A red checkered string bikini  Madison‚Äôs November 2022 honeymoon in Singapore and Bali wouldn‚Äôt be complete without some fabulous swimwear to match. Her pick for a beachside snap with her new husband, Brett Randle: a red-and-white checkered triangle-top bikini with string ties. With her husband wearing similarly hued trunks, she wrote in the caption: ‚ÄúMonkey see, monkey do.‚Äù  A sparkling striped two-piece  Madison was serving up California vibes in a April 2022 Instagram post for which she donned a sparkling string bikini with pink, purple, and blue vertical stripes. Her long, loose waves tumbled past her waist, and she showed off a perfectly polished French manicure and a dainty gold bangle bracelet.  A cutout coral bikini with body jewelry  In a January 2022 Instagram post, Madison showed off another fierce bikini ‚Äî but it was her accessories that stole the show. She modeled a coral-colored two-piece swimsuit with a cutout top and rib knit fabric.  Related  To take her look to the next level, she added a dainty gold body chain.  ‚ÄúSo thankful that body chains have had a comeback,‚Äù she wrote in the caption, tagging the designer, Nicole Rose Jewelry.  A cheeky orange bikini  Sandy cheeks were on the agenda for an August 2021 trip to Cabo. Madison shared a look at her beach day while wearing an orange and white floral string bikini.  Also on the schedule: work. Madison revealed that her Mexico trip would include time to ‚Äúcollab with one of my favorite bikini companies.‚Äù  An extra strappy velvety swimsuit  Photo: Madison LeCroy/Instagram  Clearly Madison loves a uniquely designed swimsuit, and her July 2021 look certainly fit the bill.  The hairdresser posed poolside while wearing a velvety teal swimsuit with crisscrossed straps all the way down her torso. She also wore oversized gold sunglasses, a watch and gold bangle, and had a fresh white pedicure.  A teeny floral bikini  Photo: Madison LeCroy/Instagram  Related  A trip to the Bahamas called for adorable swimwear, as seen in Madison‚Äôs March 2021 Instagram Story. In the photos, she was lounging on sandy shores while sipping a beverage ‚Äî and wearing the perfect swimsuit.  Her floral two-piece featured a colorful design on a white background and super thin straps. She added rectangular sunglasses and tied her hair back in a casual style.  A simple yet stunning white one-piece  Photo: Madison LeCroy/Instagram  While on a dreamy vacation on the Amalfi Coast in June 2019, Madison took her best swim style aboard a yacht (as one does). She picked a timeless and chic plain white one-piece swimsuit with thin straps and a scoop neckline.  For accessories, she enlisted a straw Panama hat and a bevy of gold bracelets. A nude manicure and a white pedicure finished off the look.

Amy Wilcox, a 33-year-old analyst and Richard Parker, a 37-year-old data engineer, have tied the knot.  The couple, from Leamington Spa in Warwickshire, met on a dating app 7 years ago and had their first date at a street food event at Coventry Cathedral.  "We bonded over a love of food and hatred of bananas," said the couple.  The couple got engaged at Rydal Water in October 2021.  Amy said: "We have always loved the Lake District, and we decided to have our first family holiday with our daughter in the Lakes.  "Although we had spoken about engagement rings previously, and I'd shown Rich which one I liked, I still wasn't expecting it.  "I was looking at the ducks with our daughter, and I heard Rich clear his throat and say: 'I know you've been waiting for this for a long time'.  "I remember being so happy I was crying, and there was a lot of laughter."  The pair got married at Cote How with an intimate wedding without guests.  They said they had a 'perfect' day with 'clear skies' and 'bright sunshine.'  One of the highlights of the wedding was when their favourite song, Islands in the Stream by Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers, started playing in the background.  Amy said: "It's always been one of our favourite songs and never fails to make us smile."  She added: "We had our elopement picnic outside at Cote How and it was so lovely to peacefully sit outside in such a beautiful part of the country and take it all in, just the two of us.  "We were so tired by the time we got back to the hotel that our plans to go out for dinner went out the window, and instead, we lay in bed watching Australian Survivor and eating a bag of chip shop chips and some brownies from Finch Bakery.  "It wasn't necessarily a traditional wedding day, but it was our day, and we loved it."  After the wedding, the pair spent a couple of days in the Lake District.  They also plan to spend the money they saved by having a small wedding on a big holiday in America when their daughter is older.

CHICAGO (WLS) -- ABC7 Chicago celebrates Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month with vignettes and a series of news stories and a half-hour special "Our Chicago: Changing the Narrative".  Hosted by ABC7's Judy Hsu and Ravi Baichwal, "Our Chicago: Changing the Narrative," takes a look at several leaders in Chicago making history and changes in their community for the better.  We hosted our special from the beautiful Zhou Brothers Art Center located in the historic Bridgeport neighborhood.  The half hour program airs Saturday, May 20th at 6pm, with an encore presentation on Sunday May 28th at 2pm.  Grace Pai and the TEEACH Act  Grace Pai, the executive director of Asian Americans Advancing Justice, made history in 2021 when she led a successful campaign to require Asian American history to be taught at all Illinois public schools, making Illinois the first state to do so.  "We looked at the school code. We looked at what are the requirements on histories that have often been left out," Paid said.  With its historic passage, the Teaching Equitable Asian American History Act (TEAACH) ensures that every public elementary and high school student in Illinois learns about the contributions of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders to the economic, cultural, social and political development of the United States.  Chicago's First Filipina Alderwoman, Leni Manaa- Hoppenworth  Newly elected 48th Ward Alderwoman- Leni Manaa-Hoppenworth, will be the first Filipina and queer woman of color to sit on city council.  "When we are creating policy on things that will impact the whole city of Chicago, it matters if somebody is at the table," Ald. Manaa-Hoppenworth said.  She is the daughter of Filipino immigrants who came to the states to become nurses. Manaa-Hoppenworth is a lifelong Chicagoan, living and working in the 48th Ward for more than 20 years alongside her husband and three adult children. As a progressive Democrat, she has been an active force in her community for years, including co-founding the organizations Indivisible Illinois and ILVOTE.  Joffrey's Japanese Company Dancers- Yumi Kanazawa and Yoshihisa Arai  Yumi Kanazawa, born in Tokyo, Japan, and Yoshihisa Arai, born in Hiroshima, Japan, are both company dancers at Chicago's prestigious Joffrey Ballet. Since joining The Joffrey Ballet in 2016, Kanazawa has performed in many ballets and contemporary works including Wheeldon's "Swan Lake" and "The Nutcracker".  "Joffrey Ballet is such a dream company for so many people," Kanazawa said. "And it's such a big achievement to be able to be here."  Arai began his ballet training when he was 10 years old with the International Ballet Academy and has also had a leading role in "The Nutcracker" as well as appearing as the Prince in "Cinderella." In 2018, he choreographed "Firebird Suite" for The Joffrey Ballet Studio Company. The special showcases the beauty of their dancing and explore their shared culture.  Suzanne Yoon  Suzanne Yoon has 25 years of experience in finance and has been recognized by Mergers & Acquisitions, Wall Street Journal and Chicago United.  In 2017, the Chicagoan decided to create her own business, Kinzie Capital Partners, making her one of the only women in the country to lead a private equity firm.  "I felt like if I didn't do it, and didn't try, I would regret it," Yoon said. "And I'm sure that was a lot of what was going through my mom and dad's heads when they were leaving Korea to come to the States."  Vietnam Refugee, Restaurateur and Autism Advocate - Thi Tram Nguyen  Thi Tram Nguyen was born in Vietnam during the war and, at the end of the conflict, fled the country for a better life at age 8. Her Naperville restaurant, Chez Franois Poutinerie, has a two-fold goal: to introduce poutine to area residents and provide employment opportunities to developmentally disabled adults.  "A lot of people come for the poutine, but they're going to come back for the mission," Nyugen said.  In early February, she was given the Trailblazer Award by Turning Pointe Autism Foundation for her advocacy, and she just launched a 501(c)(3) nonprofit called Friends of Franois which is committed to providing free job and social skill training to individuals with disabilities.  Indian Wedding Traditions  Jankhana Desai is a South Asian event planner who offers insight into some of the rich traditions that are part of Indian wedding culture, including the henna ceremony for the bride and the groom's barat, where he makes a grand entrance, to singing and dancing in the streets of Chicago.  "The d√©cor is outrageous, the food is outrageous and the guest list is over 500," Desai said, "I would say it's a little more elaborate than your normal wedding day."

By: Bloomberg News | May 20 2023 at 01:07 PM | Air Cargo  Georgia‚Äôs President Salome Zourabichvili said she will not use the services of the privately owned Georgian Airways following the carrier‚Äôs decision to resume commercial flights to Russia.  ‚ÄúI will refrain from using this airline from now on for as long as this company is in the hands of those people who will do anything for money,‚Äù Zourabichvili said in a public address on Saturday.  Earlier this week, other Georgian officials welcomed a decision by Russian President Vladimir Putin to restore air transport links between the two countries, even as the US and the European Union urged the government in Tbilisi to observe sanctions imposed on the Kremlin over the invasion of Ukraine.  Russia‚Äôs first commercial flight in four years landed in Georgia on Friday, spurring anti-Russian protests and stoking concern thawing relations may jeopardize the Caucasian nation‚Äôs efforts to join the EU and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.    A Georgian Airways plane landed in Moscow earlier on Saturday, according to the Tbilisi airport spokeswoman Nino Tsivtsivadze.  Zourabichvili also responded to reports that the Kvareli Lake resort in eastern Georgia is hosting a wedding organized by family members of Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.  The wedding party will not take place in Georgia, the president said in her address, adding that the family had left the country following the marriage registration.  The police have detained as many as 16 protesters at a rally outside Kvareli Lake denouncing the resort‚Äôs decision to host the wedding, according to activists present and police statements.

Palliative care nurse and her family have inspirationally created one of Ireland‚Äôs best alternative wedding venues and exclusive glamping experiences  Set on 120 acres of Kilkenny countryside with breathtaking backdrops of rolling hills, Ballyhale‚Äôs stylish and sustainable Mountain View is home to a multi-award winning wedding and events venue, luxurious and laid-back glamping village, the setting of the South East‚Äôs largest and fastest growing weekly farmer‚Äôs market and their panoramic restaurant, The Greenhouse.  Originally a family farm and having first opened nearly 30 years ago as a golf course, this third generation family-run business has been lovingly grown into one of Ireland‚Äôs most beautiful getaways and alternative wedding venues. Palliative care nurse Bee O‚ÄôGrady along with her younger brother Michael O‚ÄôNeill, from a family of 8 siblings, are the inspirational driving forces behind this truly unique must-visit countryside hideaway which overlooks miles and miles of peace and quiet.  Commenting on the success of her beautiful family-run venue, Mountain View co-owner and co-founder Bee O‚ÄôGrady says ‚ÄúAt Mountain View, we are a family. Originally my parent‚Äôs farm and along with my 8 siblings we have proudly transformed our 120 acres of rural beauty into a successful exclusive wedding and events venue, a boutique luxury glamping village, The Greenhouse restaurant with its spectacular panoramic views and of course our much-loved popular weekly farmer‚Äôs market.‚Äù  Nestled in nature, Mountain View‚Äôs beautiful boutique glamping village is the ideal alternative staycation choice for couples, families and even four-legged furry friends as they are dog friendly. This charming hilltop retreat offers a luxurious glamping experience across their spacious bell tents and custom-made Hilly Huts. Guests can expect home from home comforts in the stylish bell tents furnished with comfortable beds, luxurious duvets and fluffy pillows, while outside features your own cosy fire pit perfect for late night chats, daytime daydreaming and soaking up those spectacular sunsets. Their ‚ÄòHilly Huts‚Äô are open seasonally and are a perfect retreat for couples with their electric smart heating, a separate bathroom and shower and kitchen area for couples to enjoy a luxurious boutique glamping experience.  In addition to being home to one of Ireland‚Äôs most scenic glamping experiences, Ballyhale‚Äôs Mountain View is a multi award winning exclusive and all-inclusive wedding venue that boasts both indoor and outdoor ceremony and reception spaces on its private 120 acres. Crowned as a winner in this year‚Äôs national SaveMyDay.ie Wedding Venue Awards, Mountain View took the top spot in three award categories which is the most of any wedding venue across Ireland.. They were awarded Ireland‚Äôs Best Alternative Wedding Venue, Ireland‚Äôs Best Festival Wedding Venue and an acclaimed Judge‚Äôs Choice award.  Sharon Doyle, Director of wedding and events at Kilkenny‚Äôs award winning wedding venue Mountain View, comments ‚ÄúWhether a couple prefers to marry outdoors nestled amongst the trees or in our lovingly restored Cowshed, to party intimately in the stylish surrounds of The Greenhouse restaurant or to throw a big party celebration in the Grand Marquee, at Mountain View we will work with to-be-weds to make their wedding day truly unique and memorable for them and their guests.‚Äù  Sharon continues ‚ÄúHaving been crowned recently as Ireland‚Äôs Best Alternative and Best Festival Wedding Venue, we are delighted to announce our brand new wedding packages, ‚ÄòThe One‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe Cow Shed Feast‚Äô. Our one-of-a-kind cowshed offers the best of both worlds for wedding celebrations with its rustic and atmospheric barn-style setting and our five star top quality wedding feast from head chef Rory Nolan that prioritises the best of local and Irish produce.‚Äù  Mountain View is also famed both regionally and nationally for its glorious food including its handcrafted wedding menus and The Greenhouse restaurant with its delicious dinner, brunch, lunch and tempting cocktails. Head Chef Rory Nolan, who has worked previously at the Michelin-starred Chapter One restaurant in Dublin and Kilkenny‚Äôs Campagne under the internationally renowned chefs Ross Lewis and Garrett Byrne, puts a strong emphasis on ‚Äúsimplicity‚Äù in creating his menu and dishes and prides himself on using fresh, seasonal, locally sourced ingredients with the lowest food miles and best quality produce. Local producers include organic fruit and vegetables from Callan‚Äôs Riversfield Organic Farm; meat sourced from Mark Williams, a 6th generation beef farmer from Kilkenny‚Äôs Summerhill Farm; organic chicken from Castlecomer‚Äôs Rings Farm; and Mountain View‚Äôs own on-site herb garden.  Begun as a ‚Äòlockdown project‚Äô by the O‚ÄôNeill family, Mountain View is also the location of the South East‚Äôs largest and fastest growing weekly farmers market, Mountain View Market. Supporting hundreds of small business owners from across Ireland and showcasing on average 75 market stalls every Sunday, the much-loved Kilkenny market hosts an eclectic mix of food and craft stalls from local, regional and nationwide creators, makers, producers and businesses. From bao buns, bubble teas, sushi to award winning bakeries and vegan ‚Äòjunk‚Äô food, Mountain View Market has a wide variety of tasty food to cater for the whole family‚Äôs Sunday brunch, lunch or weekend treat. In addition to their weekly food and craft markets, Mountain View also hosts specialty markets such as vintage clothing fairs, pop up art galleries and potters markets.  The O‚ÄôNeill family and the fantastic team at Mountain View have created a truly individual and unique setting for life‚Äôs celebrations, big and small. Mountain View is a loveable, laid-back and luxurious location set on 120 acres of natural rural beauty and offers an ultimate day out and staycation experience for family, friends or even furry four-legged friends!  To find out more visit: www.mountainview.ie  Instagram for Mountain View | @mountainviewkilkenny  Facebook for Mountain View | @mountainviewkilkenny

Savor each moment of graduation experience Published 3:49 pm Saturday, May 20, 2023  By Bonnie Brown  Columnist  Since graduation has come and gone, our little town seems quieter without the students here. If you are a recent graduate, parent of a graduate, or grandparent of a graduate, congratulations!  It is a wonderful and important milestone that calls for celebration. When I worked in the Registrar‚Äôs Office, graduation was our ‚Äúparty.‚Äù We were quite involved in the ceremonies and details. One sure signal that it was time for graduation was the blooms on the Magnolia trees and all the U-Haul trucks and trailers around town.  Email newsletter signup  The set-up in the Grove is always impressive and I recall wiping the chair seats as leaf blowers were also employed in the effort to dry and clean the seats for the morning ceremony.  Parents, before you put away the checkbook thinking that you are done and have paid the last tuition payment, may I share some reasons why you won‚Äôt be able to put away that checkbook or credit card.  First, there could be the possibility of said graduate needing to put down a deposit on an  apartment or perhaps a down payment on a house near their new place of employment. No more fraternity or sorority houses. That‚Äôs where your checkbook can once again be useful.  And just when you think your offspring has settled into a nice residence, a new job, and is  adulting, along comes ‚Äúthe one.‚Äù The spouse who now makes your graduate a couple and they want a wedding. And that wedding could really eat away at your checkbook‚Äôs balance.  After the wedding, you find yourself acknowledging that you have indeed acquired another child that you love as your own. One you appreciate what he/she brings to the relationship and supports and cares for your offspring. Wonderful! Your family has expanded to include another family, one that you must now share your offspring with.  From there, if you are lucky, you may welcome a grandchild. And let me tell you, you are freer with that checkbook/credit card than you have ever been. What fun to spoil this little one who completes the family circle and has captured your heart forever.  If you are the graduate, after the celebration of graduation is over, you begin your journey into adulthood. You are now employed hopefully in a job that you find rewarding. You have a nice residence, with a nod to your parents‚Äô willingness to assist you.  You have now accepted that for your career to progress, you must put your shoulder into the effort. You are indeed now an adult. Along comes that person that completes you and you marry. Again, your parents rose to the occasion to make the wedding memorable. And before long, your family expands to include a son or daughter. You are happy and life is good.  So, I have explained to you the cycle of life after this ceremony called ‚Äúgraduation.‚Äù It is indeed an end to the educational process, the more carefree side of your offspring‚Äôs life.  And it is the beginning of the life cycle. It is only after this milestone, that you will look back and define your timeline.  I also remind you all, the parent and the offspring, to savor each and every moment. Celebrate every occasion big and small ‚Äî birthdays, holidays, family gatherings.  And remember that graduation was a defining moment. The celebration that set you all on this path.  Congratulations!  Write to Bonnie Brown at bbrown@olemiss.edu

DEAR HARRIETTE: I recently dyed my hair a fun color, and one of my girlfriends criticized me for trying to look younger than I am.  I am a 50-year-old woman, and I work in the arts. She works in a corporate job, wears a conservative hairstyle and has let her hair go gray.  I have the freedom to do what I want and look how I want, so I decided to have some fun with my hair. I didn‚Äôt appreciate her criticism.  I don‚Äôt want to come off as overly sensitive, but I do want her to know that I feel perfectly comfortable and happy with my playful hair. I don‚Äôt judge her for how she wears hers.  Related Articles Advice | Harriette Cole: My friend is too lenient in her parenting, but she thrusts advice on me  Harriette Cole: My friend is too lenient in her parenting, but she thrusts advice on me Advice | Harriette Cole: My friend wouldn‚Äôt pay when I forgot my wallet. Do I confront her?  Harriette Cole: My friend wouldn‚Äôt pay when I forgot my wallet. Do I confront her? Advice | Harriette Cole: My boss may be losing her memory, and it‚Äôs causing chaos  Harriette Cole: My boss may be losing her memory, and it‚Äôs causing chaos Advice | Harriette Cole: I‚Äôm going to be seething if this kid sticks with his summer routine  Harriette Cole: I‚Äôm going to be seething if this kid sticks with his summer routine Advice | Harriette Cole: My girlfriend canceled our vacation because of what her father said Should I say something or keep it to myself?  To Each Her Own  DEAR TO EACH HER OWN: Don‚Äôt go out of your way to admonish your friend.  Enjoy your new look. If she ever mentions it again, you can tell her that it hurts your feelings a bit when she is critical of your hair color.  You can remind her that you work in a field that allows you freedom of expression, and you chose to exercise that freedom. She has the right to her opinion, and you have the right to do what you want.  Point out that you have never made disparaging comments about her hair, and you would appreciate her extending you the same courtesy.  DEAR HARRIETTE: I‚Äôm going to the wedding of the daughter of a woman I grew up with. I haven‚Äôt seen them for years because I moved away when I went to college.  I don‚Äôt know why, but I‚Äôm feeling like this is almost like a class reunion when people stand around and look each other up and down and judge them on how the years have treated them.  Am I being harsh? Yes. But I have gained at least 50 pounds since I saw them last. I know how to dress myself and all, but I know they will be shocked when they see me. Heck, I‚Äôm shocked when I look in the mirror!  How can I prepare myself for what they will do or say? I am feeling extremely uncomfortable about facing people. I‚Äôm thinking I should just send a gift and skip the wedding.  Uncomfortable in My Skin  DEAR UNCOMFORTABLE IN MY SKIN: Guess what? Just like at a class reunion, you will most assuredly not be the only one who has gained weight since the last time you got together.  By all means, go to the wedding. Dress your best and check your attitude.  You are attending the most joyous occasion for your friend‚Äôs daughter. Focus on that. All eyes will be on the bride. When someone‚Äôs gaze lands on you, smile and talk to them.  Don‚Äôt say anything about your body. Ask them about their lives. Tell them about yours. Enjoy yourself. You can compliment people on things you like about their presentation or their stories.  If someone skittishly talks about how they look now, admit that you were a little uncomfortable, too, but you are so glad you showed up.  Harriette Cole is a lifestylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com or c/o Andrews McMeel Syndication, 1130 Walnut St., Kansas City, MO 64106.

Previously, in Bora! Deborah, Deborah and Su Hyeok‚Äôs relationship took a step further as they went from hating each other to realizing that they had been each other‚Äôs support system since they met. Moreover, both of them received a wedding invitation from Su Hyeok‚Äôs ex-girlfriend, Yu Ri. Su Hyeok was out of sorts after he received the invitation, so Deborah couldn‚Äôt tell him that he didn‚Äôt need to feel so hurt because Yu Ri was two-timing him. A few days before her wedding, Yu Ri called Su Hyeok because she missed him. Deborah knew she had to stop him because she couldn‚Äôt see Su Hyeok being any more miserable than he already was.  Spoilers Ahead  Will Su Hyeok Keep His Promise To Deborah?  Deborah had to attend a friend‚Äôs engagement, and Su Hyeok had agreed to tag along with her to make things less uncomfortable for others as Ju Wan was going to attend as well, and also to make Ju Wan jealous. However, as they are on their way to the engagement ceremony, Su Hyeok tries to bail on her to meet Yu Ri. Deborah lets him go at first but later stops him because she is worried that he might get hurt more. She doesn‚Äôt tell him the real reason, but she urges him to keep his promise to go to the ceremony. They get into a fight over it, but Su Hyeok won‚Äôt back down. He decides to go and meet Yu Ri but also promises Deborah that he will attend the engagement ceremony as well. Deborah goes to the ceremony as she had already promised her friend, and she gets ridiculed over her breakup with Ju Wan, as she expected. Meanwhile, Su Hyeok meets Yu Ri, who is drunk. She called Su Hyeok after running away from her boyfriend while trying on wedding dresses. She is scared and anxious, but seeing her in this state, Su Hyeok becomes calm and collected, as he needs to handle her. Yu Ri and Su Hyeok needed closure in their relationship so that Yu Ri could stop hating Su Hyeok, and he could stop regretting losing her.  Su Hyeok and Yu Ri talk things out and say everything that was left out. Both of them are finally free from the burden of their breakup and wish each other well. Yu Ri notices that Su Hyeok has changed a lot, and he also realizes the same and wonders if it is because of Deborah. He goes to the engagement ceremony just in time for Ju Wan to arrive as well. Su Hyeok not only makes Ju Wan jealous, but the rest of the women are jealous of Deborah as well. However, they do not declare that they are dating, and Deborah just introduces him as a friend. Their chemistry is so good that even Yu Jeong feels that something is really going on between the two. Their plan works, and Ju Wan starts messaging Deborah. They end up meeting each other, and Deborah feels relieved after talking to him. It puts her heart at ease knowing that he was never the right guy for her, and neither was she the right woman for him. Meanwhile, her sisters, Bo Mi and Jin Ho, are having a good time as their young love blooms. Su Hyeok has been happier since he sorted things out with Yu Ri and is flirting more with Deborah. Both of them don‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs going on between them, but they are too afraid to tackle that question.  Why Does Sang Jin Reject Woo Ri?  Deborah and Su Hyeok go on a movie date with the excuse of doing research. It was Su Hyeok‚Äôs idea, and lately, he has been coming up with many innovative ideas to spend time with Deborah. They accidentally run into Su Hyeok‚Äôs parents, but neither of them is awkward. Su Hyeok‚Äôs mother is happy to finally see her son with a woman. Su Hyeok never talks about his parents, but he tells Deborah that he has a stepfather. He is on good terms with his stepfather, but seeing his mother get divorced affected him deeply. He became reclusive at the time, and since then, he hasn‚Äôt been able to express his feelings freely because it made him anxious. However, he has decided to change himself now. Meanwhile, Sang Jin finally finds the courage to clear things up with Woo Ri over her one-sided crush on him. Woo Ri has been hinting at him for quite some time, and even though he likes her, he finds it wrong to date her. He is way older than her and is also divorced. He rejects her even before she confesses her feelings. On the other hand, Su Hyeok won‚Äôt stop flirting with Deborah and even asks her to pretend to be his girlfriend at Yu Ri‚Äôs wedding. When he went to meet Yu Ri, her fiance saw them together, so he lied about being high school friends and said that he would bring his girlfriend to the wedding.  Sang Jin and Su Jin are also at Yu Ri‚Äôs wedding, as they are mutual friends. They meet their old friends at the wedding, but they start mocking Sang Jin for his divorce and keep pestering him to give them the reason. Sang Jin doesn‚Äôt know how to respond to them, so Su Jin comes to his rescue. She mocks all the married couples in return and leaves the wedding hall with Sang Jin. Sang Jin had been trying to talk things out with Su Jin, but she never gave him a chance. He finally has a chance now, and he speaks up. Right before their divorce, Sang Jin‚Äôs business was on the verge of going bankrupt, and he was struggling to pay debts to many people. He wasn‚Äôt mentally well enough to spend romantic time with Su Jin. Su Jin feels upset and realizes that she is also at fault. Sang Jin couldn‚Äôt rely on her when he was going through a tough phase in his life, but she blamed him for all the wrong reasons. However, this conversation leads them to resolve all their hard feelings toward each other. Su Jin apologizes to him, and they are back to being friends.  Su Hyeok‚Äôs flirting game is going well, and he is giving Deborah every reason to get flustered. He compliments her when she says that she doesn‚Äôt feel confident about herself. He is also subtly hinting that he likes her, but Deborah is not getting it. She still wants to believe that Su Hyeok is just a good friend. However, at the end of Episode 12 of Bora! Deborah, Deborah finds out something that she thinks is too good to be true. While going through an old collection of pictures from another friend‚Äôs wedding, she sees Su Hyeok in one of the pictures. At her friend‚Äôs engagement ceremony recently, Su Hyeok mentioned how he fell in love at first sight with Deborah when he saw her at a wedding a few years ago. Now, Deborah can‚Äôt help but wonder if his story was true and not really made up.

By India Today Entertainment Desk: Sara Ali Khan and Vicky Kaushal will be seen together in Zara Hatke Zara Bachke. The film will see the duo play a married couple who are heading for a divorce because they feel their marriage has become stagnant. At the trailer launch, Sara was seen joking about Vicky Kaushal‚Äôs wedding and mentioned how it is her energy which makes her co-stars run away and get married.  advertisement  SARA ON HER CO-STARS GETTING MARRIED  At the trailer launch event which was held on Monday, May 15, Sara spoke about Vicky‚Äôs wedding to Katrina Kaif and said, "He is the fourth actor jo mere saath shooting karte karte shaadi kar leta hai.‚Äù Vicky Kaushal shared that anyone who wanted to get married should work with her.  READ | Cannes 2023: Sara Ali Khan‚Äôs dripping dress is the ultimate blingtastic number  To this, Sara jokingly added, "Main bol chuki hoon, jisko bhi shaadi karni hai aur jin auraton ko shaadi karwani hai (I've said it before, anyone to wants to get married, or any women who want their partners to marry), just make them sign a film with me. I think there's something about my energy that makes them want to run away and get married immediately."  WHAT IS ALL THIS ABOUT?  Vicky married Katrina in December 2021. Sara had earlier worked with Ranveer Singh on Simmba, Varun Dhawan on Coolie No 1 and Vikrant Massey on Gaslight. All the three actors are now married.  Co-written by Laxman, Maitrey Bajpai and Ramiz Khan, Zara Hatke Zara Bachke will release in theatres on June 2, 2023.

In January, I attended my first ever wedding. Later, I mentioned the event in passing at my publisher‚Äôs office. ‚ÄúWait,‚Äù someone said. ‚ÄúYou wrote a whole book about a wedding before you‚Äôd been to one?‚Äù  At that stage I had signed off on the final proofs of my second novel, The Happy Couple. Matrimony structures the plot; the first chapter opens with the couple getting engaged, and we follow them as the ceremony draws near. Why choose this setup when I‚Äôd never attended a wedding? Because I thought it would make a good book. To me, marriage is like extreme sports: I‚Äôm thrilled for those who partake, and have zero interest in joining them.  Marriage is a nifty narrative device. It brings together people who don‚Äôt normally meet, and occasions heaps of conflict. Also, it‚Äôs accessible. Everyone knows at least the basics of how their culture gets hitched. We acquire this familiarity as much from art as from life. That‚Äôs how I could write a novel about a wedding without ever having been to one. I researched some of the finer points, but I was largely able to rely on the knowledge I‚Äôve absorbed from decades of media immersion, from books and poems, from paintings and song lyrics and movies.  What will become of the marriage plot in art and literature as the actual marriage rate declines? It‚Äôs a question we‚Äôve been asking for decades; Jeffrey Eugenides‚Äôs 2011 novel The Marriage Plot offers a postmodern spin on the issue. Its heroine, reading English at Brown University, has to choose between two different men while studying virtuoso marriage plotters Jane Austen and George Eliot.  Marriage rates have since plunged even lower. That young people are tying fewer knots has triggered angst in certain quarters, though it‚Äôs hardly surprising. It‚Äôs hard enough these days for most young couples to rent a flat, never mind spend hundreds of pounds on a cake. But the real conservative bugbear isn‚Äôt that fewer people can afford to get married; it‚Äôs that fewer people actually want to. That fewer people are entering long-term romantic relationships, or seeking public validation when they do commit. That fewer people are judging themselves against traditional measures of success, or longing for a nuclear family.  When we look at post-wedding life in Austen‚Äôs novels, the success rate of marriage seems mixed at best  For the avoidance of doubt, I‚Äôm not suggesting that couples who marry can‚Äôt think for themselves. Actually, marriage nowadays is a much more active and informed choice than it was a few decades ago, precisely because it‚Äôs no longer the default. Those with personal, specific reasons are still getting married ‚Äì people like my newlywed friends. But the number of people who marry in order to conform is dropping off.  It follows that the traditional marriage plot will change in art as it has in life. The popular idea is that 19th-century female novelists romanticised marriage ‚Äì Eliot, the Bront√´ sisters, and, above all, Austen. A ‚ÄúJane Austen ending‚Äù is supposedly a happily-ever-after. But when we look at post-wedding life in Austen‚Äôs novels, the success rate of marriage seems mixed at best. Besides a handful of exceptions (the Westons in Emma, say, or the Crofts in Persuasion), most spouses are either bickering or dead. Yes, we‚Äôre generally told in the final chapter that the heroine‚Äôs post-nuptial happiness will last ‚Äì but Austen‚Äôs love of irony warns that we shouldn‚Äôt necessarily take the narrator‚Äôs conclusion at face value.  In 20th-century anglophone literature, the theme of marriage still dominates ‚Äì but rather than the events leading up to a wedding, we‚Äôre more likely to see what happens next. Marital (and extramarital) relations lie at the heart of James Joyce‚Äôs Ulysses, DH Lawrence‚Äôs Lady Chatterley‚Äôs Lover, Virginia Woolf‚Äôs Mrs Dalloway and the work of Toni Morrison, a committed Janeite who devoured Austen‚Äôs novels throughout her childhood. While not predominately concerned with marriage, Morrison‚Äôs novels nevertheless present a similarly nuanced portrayal of the institution. As with Austen, there‚Äôs the good (marriage as an exercise of agency between enslaved people in Beloved), the bad (Mavis‚Äôs abusive husband in Paradise), and the ugly (literally all the couples in Song of Solomon).  Then there are the groundbreaking portrayals of same-sex relationships, with all their realistic flaws, in the work of authors such as James Baldwin, Djuna Barnes and Jane Bowles. While such depictions still don‚Äôt dominate mainstream art, they‚Äôve certainly become more accessible in the 21st century. Brandon Taylor‚Äôs second novel, The Late Americans, centres on a gay friendship group where no single character must ‚Äúrepresent‚Äù their entire community; the tension in Douglas Stuart‚Äôs Young Mungo and Shehan Karunatilaka‚Äôs The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida comes as much from community strife as from forbidden love between two men.  From the UK publication of Kristen Arnett‚Äôs novel With Teeth to Todd Field‚Äôs film T√°r, starring Cate Blanchett, 2022 was a year of believable, therefore-sometimes-disastrous same-sex marriages. Meanwhile Akwaeke Emezi‚Äôs novels and Liv Little‚Äôs recent debut Rosewater take the beauty of queer love as their undisputed thematic core.  skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Bookmarks Free weekly newsletter Discover new books with our expert reviews, author interviews and top 10s. Literary delights delivered direct you Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy . We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. after newsletter promotion  So where does all this leave the marriage plot? Well, it depends on the author. One can still write a convincing novel with wedlock at the centre: Monica Ali did so excellently in Love Marriage. But this testifies more to Ali‚Äôs dramatic talents than to the contemporary importance of marriage. Show a character caring about something, and the audience will care, too ‚Äì whether it‚Äôs a birthday party, a frisbee contest, or a wedding. Novelists will probably always be able to persuade us that marriage is important to their characters. But they‚Äôll have to do the work. They can no longer rely on the reader bringing that assumption to the page.  I did not write my second novel about marriage with a rabid desire to tear the whole thing down. I am not aiming to inspire a wave of divorces, though of course I‚Äôll take it as a compliment if I do. But I did want to approach my fictional wedding with non-judgmental curiosity, tailoring the plot to the characters‚Äô peculiarities rather than forcing a ready-to-wear outcome. I considered what made sense for my protagonists, what they‚Äôd want, how they‚Äôd behave. Once I‚Äôd worked all that out, the rest was just typing.  That‚Äôs what I want for real people, too: an awareness of what‚Äôs right for them, and the resources to bring it about. Marriage can only benefit from continuing to become less of an obligation and more of a choice. Romance itself need not be a prerequisite for personal fulfilment; we were all, in my view, put on this planet to do whatever the hell we want. The more willing we become in real life to accept unconventional happy endings, the more emboldened novelists will feel to bring them to the page.

Get the latest news from Peaky Blinders straight to your inbox  Family feuds are among the most volatile situations which can all too frequently end in violence. Petty squabbles can quickly get out of hand and escalate to attacks on the streets.  Hurt pride and damaged egos can often overrule any sense of diplomacy or a desire to resolve things peacefully. This year we have covered a number of criminal cases involving long-running disputes including rows within the same family as well as rivalries between two separate packs.  Read through our roundup below which includes a trio showoff brothers compared to the Peaky Blinders, sisters-in-law who plunged a wedding into chaos and a 'public act of war' which resulted in the murder of a dad.  READ MORE: Drunk man left Ryanair passengers scared with antics on flight to Birmingham  Driver ran over friend 'like a skittle' after row over his wife    (Image: West Midlands Police)  Mohammed Hassan mowed down his friend 'like a skittle' following a dispute over his wife. The 46-year-old performed a U-turn and then drove over the victim again in Garrison Lane, Small Heath.  Previously, Hassan had arranged for his friend to marry his former sister-in-law but regretted the move and launched a campaign of harassment as he tried to control her. In one incident he removed her from the property and attacked her.  A couple of days later he met with his friend to hash out their differences but they ended up arguing. Hassan grabbed his friend's beard, who in-turn pulled the handbrake on the car to get out. It was then that he was ran over.  Hassan of Rollaston Road, Dudley, was convicted of attempted murder as well as pleading guilty to causing serious injury by dangerous driving and harassment. He was sentenced to 21 years.  Showoff Solihull brothers told 'you are not the Peaky Blinders' amid family feud  (Image: Birmingham Live)  Abbas brothers Ali, Zain and Bilal together with relative Mohammed Javed caused havoc on Coventry Road, Small Heath as they targeted a family member following a long-running feud. They turned up in a Volkswagen Golf, some armed with weapons, and started shouting: 'We're here to kill you' and 'we're going to f*** you up'.  Javed drove the Golf back and forth at speed before Zain Abbas got into the victim's Mercedes van and drove off. Two people suffered minor injuries as they were struck by vehicles in the incident.  The Abbas brothers, of The Crescent in Solihull, and Javed, of Coleshill Road, Marston Green, admitted affray and were sentenced to 12-month community orders. Zain Abbas and Javed also pleaded guilty to dangerous driving and were banned from the roads for a year.  Judge Richard Bond compared the family to the notorious Birmingham gang who were associated with Small Heath in the 1890s but he told them: 'You are not the Peaky Blinders '. Outside Birmingham Crown Court the defendants posed for pictures in front of a luxury black car before leaving.  Mum of nine put on tag after taking 'revenge' on sister-in-law at wedding  (Image: Birmingham Live)  Halima Ahmed threw a plate at her sister-in-law Zainab Ahmed at a wedding in Small Heath leaving her disabled. They got into a row at the Bia Lounge Wedding Hall having fallen out a few years earlier.  Zainab, 57, threw a biscuit at Halima, 55, who launched a flask of coffee which fortunately missed. Halima then tossed the plate which Zainab was able to deflect away but to the cost of her arm which suffered a deep cut resulting in ongoing problems.  Halima, a mum-of-nine, of Dirleton Road, Newham, in London, admitted unlawful wounding. She was spared prison, partly due to her poor physical health and the impact it would have on her youngest children. She was instead sentenced to 12 months suspended for 18 months, which included a 16-week electronically monitored curfew between 8pm and 6am.  How bitter family feud escalated to violent murder of dad on his birthday  Hassan Tasleem and Gurdeep Sandhu murdered taxi-boss Mohammed Haroon Zeb in a 'public act of war' amid a bitter feud between two rival families. They killed him in a drive-by shooting as the 39-year-old dad-of-four pulled up outside his home in Queens Cross, Dudley, shortly after 12.30am on January 31, 2021.  Tasleem pulled the trigger of a revolver five times from a Volkswagen Golf driven by Sandhu, who slowed down to put him in position. Mr Zeb, who was killed on his birthday, was not thought to be involved in the wider feud which had included previous acts of violence and another murder.  Tasleem, 25, of Richmond Road, Dudley, and Sandhu, 25, of Blowers Green Road, Dudley, were convicted of murder, possession of a firearm with intent to endanger life and perverting the course of justice. They were both sentenced for life and a minimum 30 years in jail.  Shamraz Ali, aged 21, of Tanfield Road, Dudley, was convicted of perverting the course of justice and sentenced to five years.  Bare-chested thug 'blowing kisses' picked up woman by her hair and stabbed her  (Image: WMP)  Brandon Holmes and Dale Holmes reacted violently after a dispute between two families erupted in Weoley Castle. Following an exchange of abusive messages a group, made up of men and women, went to an address in Barcheston Road during the early hours of the morning.  A confrontation ensued and Brandon Holmes dragged a woman by the hair, punched her in the face and then stabbed her in the back four times. He also uploaded a mocking video of the incident to Snapchat.  Brandon Holmes, aged 25, of Barcheston Road, Weoley Castle, admitted wounding with intent, unlawful wounding and assault. He was sentenced to ten years. Dale Holmes, 32, of the same address, received ten months for pleading guilty to unlawful wounding for his involvement. The wedding cake flavour is the next best thing to the design. With the new trending flavours on the market, intending couples are spoilt for choice, but they need to be careful when choosing.    Fatia Hassan, the Marketing Manager of Cafe Javas says that many non-traditional flavours can be incorporated into a wedding cake.    "For example caramel and coconut, chocolate fudge and vanilla, red velvet, and others. The couple decides to use their favourite flavours in harmony," she says.    There is also the option of having a different flavour for each cake tier.    "Some rich flavours like chocolate fudge can be overwhelming so another way to present them is in the form of cupcakes or slices for guests. Alternatively, there can be smaller size tiers alongside the main cake," she reveals.    Other desserts like ice cream alongside the cake are great, but the couple needs to have practical ways to keep it frozen.    "You cannot expect the ice cream to stay in its form for two hours, but instead there are macarons as an alternative form of dessert," she advised.    The intending couple should start looking for their wedding cake service provider as soon as the wedding date is set and must book a cake-tasting session with their provider.    "They should strive to create rapport between themselves and the service providers so that they communicate their desires well," she says.    Hassan says that majority of the trending cake flavours are delicate and need to be consumed a few days after the wedding because the cake is usually freshly baked and has no preservatives so it might go stale if poorly kept for long.    She says for the few days it is still available refrigerate it for better preservation.    The Bride and Groom expo 2023 will be awash with the best wedding cake service providers, from whom a couple can choose.  The event is slated for 23-25 th June at the UMA main exhibition hall in Lugogo. The entrance fee is sh10,000 and gates will be open from 8 am.

So far, the video has received over 3 million views and is still increasing. One user also wrote, ‚ÄúBeautiful either with it or without it."  Jefferies, aged 36, and Fayed, aged 30, have been in a relationship since 2017. I was never a fan of marriage rituals, especially those borrowed from Bollywood. Juta chhupana (hiding the groom‚Äôs shoes) was not a part of marriage ceremonies in my family till Hum Aapke Hain Kaun became a wedding template for Indians.  I was in principle against the concept of demanding money from my elder sister‚Äôs groom for a pair of shoes he had already paid for. So, when my cousins insisted on hiding my brother-in-law‚Äôs mojari, I decided to guard it instead. My cousins had the last laugh as they negotiated the shoes for Rs 5,000 and divided it among themselves. My failed attempt to protect the shoes became a family joke, but I never regretted my decision to not be a part of that ‚Äúextortion‚Äù bid. My non-participation was my will.  That year was 2005. The next wedding in my family took place over a decade later, in the month PM Narendra Modi made the demonetisation announcement. My brother‚Äôs wedding was fixed on November 24, 2016. That wedding, I spent almost entirely waiting in bank queues in my hometown in Bihar, hoping to withdraw Rs 10,000 per day from four different banks.  I watched my brother from a distance as women, mostly married aunts and cousins, applied haldi on his face and body. My mother, given her ‚Äòwidowed‚Äô status (my father had passed away in 2011), did not want to take part in the ritual and I, the unmarried elder sister in charge of organising the wedding, had several other things to manage ‚Äî decorators, gen sets, halwais, bandwallahs and wedding shopping.  Not many missed me. They needed a byahta (married woman) to perform the rituals and my sister was the obvious choice. My single status left them confused. Should I be allowed to take part in the ceremonies? I, too, didn‚Äôt volunteer, perhaps in the same fix as my mother when it came to marriage rituals. How could I convince her when I lacked clarity myself? Being single isn‚Äôt easy and explaining your status to others is worse. It‚Äôs this awkwardness, I guess, that pushes most single women away from crowded family functions.  On the day of the wedding, my sister decided to stay home to prepare for the bride‚Äôs welcome the next day. My mother had already declared that she won‚Äôt go with the baarat and I volunteered to stay with them. There were too many relatives ready to ‚Äúrepresent‚Äù us at the wedding.  In the afternoon, as the baarat preparations began, an uncle told me we could withdraw Rs 25,000 by showing the wedding card at the bank.  Advertisement  I ran to the nearest branch, but a crowd had already gathered there, a wedding card in each hand. I don‚Äôt know how many of those cards were fake, but the bank soon ran out of cash. I was worried about getting late for the baarat. I wanted to see if my brother‚Äôs sherwani had been altered correctly and if the mojari matched it. I wanted to be there when he wore the maur (headgear) and protect him from overenthusiastic aunts trying to ward off evil eyes with extra coats of kajal.  By 5 pm, a bank employee handed me a bundle of Rs 500 notes and I ran to my home, barely 500 metres away. At the door, my uncle told me the baarat departure had been advanced by an hour due to traffic issues. Standing on the stairs, sweating on a cold November evening in a cotton salwar-kurta, I felt like an outsider at my brother‚Äôs wedding. I hugged him and slipped the cash into his pocket. The baarat left with our relatives. My sister and mother stood at the door, teary-eyed.  Looking at myself, I felt cheated. ‚ÄúYou said you didn‚Äôt want to go,‚Äù she said, holding my hand. My eyes fell on our hands. Those were the only palms without henna colours. I guess this time my non-participation was everyone‚Äôs will.

Mother takes action over son‚Äôs mystery death after wedding  By Tsai Shu-yuan, Chang Jui-chen and Jake Chung / Staff reporters, with staff writer      The mother of a student, who died on May 4, on Friday accused a man of tricking her son into a same-sex marriage to gain legal rights to his inheritance, NT$500 million (US$16.3 million) of land.  The son, surnamed Lai (Ë≥¥), fell to his death from a 10th-floor residence in Taichung owned by a man surnamed Sia (Â§è).  The mother told a news conference that Sia, an assistant at a land administration company owned by Lai‚Äôs father, on May 4 invited Lai out, promising that he would ‚Äúteach him how to handle his real estate.‚Äù  A woman speaks at a news conference in Taichung on Friday at which she accused a man of tricking her son into a same-sex marriage to gain legal rights to his inheritance. Photo: Tsai Shu-yuan, Taipei Times  However, Sia took Lai to the Household Registration Office in Beitun District (ÂåóÂ±Ø) to register themselves as a same-sex couple, the mother said.  Lai died less than two hours after the marriage certificate was issued, she said.  Sia‚Äôs actions suggested premeditation, as he had asked Lai to transfer the deeds for the land to the company, she said.  The Taichung District Prosecutors‚Äô Office said that it has listed Sia as a suspect in the case, adding that he posted bail of NT$300,000 after detention was deemed unnecessary.  The Civil Code stipulates that same-sex marriages give partners the same legal rights as other marriages, including inheritance rights.  A lawyer for the mother, surnamed Hsu (Ë®±), told the news conference that the marriage was ‚Äúabsurd,‚Äù as the two had only met twice, with the first time being last month.  Lai‚Äôs mother said that her son had recently started university and had been looking for a girlfriend.  The witnesses to the marriage had been two random people, she said.  The prosecutors‚Äô office said that an autopsy had been conducted on May 12 and it was awaiting the report.  A funeral parlor said that despite Lai falling 10 stories, his body was largely intact, with only one broken arm and little sign of blood, Chinese-language media reported.  Lai inherited 30 plots of land from his paternal grandfather, who was also his biological father, the reports said.  The grandfather had slept with Lai‚Äôs mother, an immigrant from China who was married to one of his sons, they said, adding that the father, who died last month, had adopted Lai.

Sarah Jessica Parker paid tribute to her husband Matthew Broderick on their 26th wedding anniversary.  On Saturday, the Sex And The City actress seemingly shared some of the details of how the couple celebrated their marriage milestone in an Instagram post that featured the simple photo of a champagne cork.  'Happy 26th anniversary, my husband,' Parker, 58, began in the caption. 'That sure was a nice celebration and a real nice bottle of champagne. And a gorgeous walk home.'  She ended the special post by reflecting back on the many years they have shared: 'Oh the miles we have strolled together. I love you. XOX, your SJ.'  The couple first met back in November 1991 when her brothers Pippin and Tobey Parker co-founded the Naked Angels Theater Company in New York City, and Broderick was hired to direct one of the plays, according to People.  Marriage milestone: Sarah Jessica Parker, 58, paid tribute to her husband Matthew Broderick, 61, on their 26th wedding anniversary on Saturday; pictured in 2022  Founded in 1986, Naked Angels would 'soon became the 'it' place for rising young actors and playwrights that also included the likes of Marisa Tomei, Mary Stuart Masterson, Gina Gershon, Helen Slater and Rob Morrow, among many others.  About five-and-a-half-years later, the couple decided to make their union legal and tie-the-knot, but they didn't let their 1000 guest know ahead of time.  Wanting to surprise everyone, they sent out a standard party invitation, which ultimately led to them exchanging their vows at the Angel Oresanz Synagogue on the Lower East Side of Downtown Manhattan.  The intimate civil ceremony was followed by a reception full of show tunes that continued into the overnight hours, according to Brides.  In a move to avoid attracting attention to their surprise wedding, the fashionista would reveal she wore a ruffled, black Morgane Le Fay dress for her wedding, and confess that it was the first thing she saw when she bought it off the rack.  'I was too embarrassed to get married in white, and both Matthew and I were reluctant to have people pay so much attention to us,' the Nelsonville, Ohio native told Marie Claire in 2006.  A few years later the And Just Like That... star revealed she would wear white if she ever has a chance to renew her vows.  During their 26 years of marriage, the couple welcomed three children: son James, 20, and twin daughters Tabitha and Marion, 13.  Cheers: The Sex And The City actress seemingly shared some of the details of how the couple celebrated their anniversary in an Instagram post that featured a photo of a champagne cork  Destiny: After meeting in November 1991 at the Naked Angels Theater Company in New York City, the couple decided to tie-the-knot with a surprise wedding on May 19, 1997  Surprise wedding! In order to keep their wedding a surprise, Parker and Broderick sent out a standard party invitation to about 100 friends, which ultimately led to them exchanging their vows at the Angel Oresanz Synagogue on the Lower East Side of Downtown Manhattan  Bride in black: Parker revealed she wore a ruffled, black Morgane Le Fay dress for her surprise wedding, and that it was the first thing she saw when she bought it off the rack; the couple are pictured in 1997 around the time they exchanged their vows  Family matters: During their 26 years of marriage, the couple welcomed three children: son James, 20, and twin daughters Tabitha and Marion, 13; Pictured in 2022  In an interview last year, Broderick, 61, confessed that he knew right away that he would marry Parker.  'Oh, the first time I met her,' the Ferris Bueller's Day Off star told Andy Cohen while on Watch What Happens Live, adding, 'I saw her walking down the street and thought "That's it."'  When asked what he admires the most about his wife, the Tony Award winning actor responded, 'Humor and wisdom.'  Parker is set to return to the Sex And The City sequel series, And Just Like That... when season two premieres on HBO max on June 22.  As for the latest on Broderick's career, the New York City native stars in the upcoming coming of age comedy film, No Hard Feelings, alongside Jennifer Lawrence and Andrew Barth Feldman, that premieres in theaters on June 23.

FORMER Strictly Come Dancing star Greg Rutherford has revealed he has postponed his wedding day. Susie and Greg have been together since 2012 and got engaged in May 2019.  Alongside two-year-old Daphne share two sons; eight-year-old Milo, and five-year-old Rex.
