They also talk about other outdated rules like matching outfits for the bridal party, parents paying for the event, and more.May 17, 2023

For many couples, what they'll wear on the actual wedding is usually the only fashion consideration they make when planning their upcoming nuptials. And while selecting a ceremony gown and tuxedo is an extremely important task, for those who are currently planning multiple events, there are several other outfits you need to consider. From what you'll wear to the engagement party and the rehearsal dinner to outfits for the bachelor or bachelorette party and post-wedding brunch, your complete wedding wardrobe is an opportunity to showcase your personal style and create a cohesive look from start to finish.  With all this in mind, it's normal to feel a lot of pressure when attempting to curate the "perfect" capsule wardrobe. Not only will you need to coordinate with your partner, but you also have to consider your personal aesthetics, each event's theme, where they'll be held, and the level of formality, among other things. Before you get completely overwhelmed, though, we'd like to highlight that these supplementary outfits provide you with the freedom to test out new fashions and reflect your status as the bride or groom. It's also your chance to incorporate pops of color, seasonal fabrics, or trending accessories that may not be suitable for your actual nuptials. Sounds fun, right?  Ahead, we spoke with two stylists for their expert advice on planning the ultimate wedding wardrobe. Here's everything you need to know, from when to buy your outfits to styling tips to remember.  Meet the Expert Hope LaVine is a bridal stylist based in Santa Monica, California. She‚Äôs also a content creator that provides brides with wedding inspiration and advice via her TikToks, quizzes, and Pinterest boards.  Raina Silberstein is a fashion stylist and luxury personal shopper based in Los Angeles, California. She helps clients define their personal style and build a wardrobe for work, special events, and more.  PHOTOS BY ADRIANA RIVERA and REBECCA YALE PHOTOGRAPHY; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  What to Consider When Planning Your Wedding Wardrobe  Before you start shopping for your wedding wardrobe, both Rania Silberstein, a fashion stylist and luxury personal shopper, and Hope LaVine, a bridal stylist, recommend deciding on an overall creative vision. That way, you can select outfits that complement the vibe of your events while also taking the season, level of formality, and event design into consideration. For instance, if you‚Äôre planning a party on the beach, ‚Äúan overall relaxed style may be best," Silberstein says. "Opt for lightweight textiles like a linen suit or take cues from the coastal color palette. Planning a downtown city celebration? Neutrals and shine make a chic formula along with sleek silhouettes that mirror the architecture.‚Äù  Silberstein also advises couples to use their personal style and everyday wardrobe as inspiration. ‚ÄúIf you often choose bold styles in your wardrobe, forgo traditional options like a white gown or black tuxedo,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúI would avoid trying something entirely new and out of your personal comfort level, whether that is a color, pattern, texture, or silhouette.‚Äù That‚Äôs not to say you can‚Äôt experiment with your ensembles, but the key to creating a fantastic look is by bringing together fashion elements you already love with a few statement details.  Lastly, you‚Äôll want to think about wearability. ‚ÄúI would want to invest in high quality, gorgeous pieces that I would wear in new ways,‚Äù LaVine says. ‚ÄúI think your wedding wardrobe should be pretty interchangeable‚Äîa corset you wore for your bachelorette, then wear on a Friday date night with the spouse. I think if we invest in better quality pieces up front, then we will have it in our closet forever.‚Äù  PHOTO BY ADRIANA RIVERA; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  When to Buy Your Wedding Wardrobe  While it‚Äôs highly recommended that you buy a wedding dress or suit several months before the big day, the shopping timeline for your other celebrations isn't as restrictive. Specifically, Silberstein suggests that couples purchase their outfits in the same season as their events. ‚ÄúBy sourcing your outfit closer to the event date, you discover relevant styles, colors, and textiles for the time of year,‚Äù she notes. ‚ÄúResort styles may appeal for your summer tropical welcome party, while rich velvets are beautiful for a winter engagement event.‚Äù  She further notes that everyone should book their venue spaces before deciding on their outfits, as the location ‚Äúwill set the tone for the entire event from the design elements to the overall vibe. The wedding attire should complement the vision too.‚Äù Finally, once you‚Äôve secured dates for your events, Silberstein and LaVine both recommend finalizing your outfit about two to three weeks beforehand to allow for any potential outfit changes, alternations, and delayed shipping.  For the bride, LaVine suggests purchasing a wedding gown first before you focus on anything else. ‚ÄúAfter that, I like to switch back to more ‚Äòhigh stakes‚Äô looks like rehearsal dinner and reception (if there is a dress change),‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAfter securing those outfits, I tend to prioritize the bachelorette party looks last. They‚Äôre a little easier to buy for and have tons of options out there.‚Äù As for the groom, LaVine recommends that his look should not only compliment the event's aesthetic but should also pair well with the bride's attire‚Äîmeaning, the groom should purchase his outfits once everything else has been locked in.  How to Make Your Wedding Wardrobes Cohesive  A bride‚Äôs look tends to take top priority for most wedding events, but it‚Äôs important to put some thought into the groom‚Äôs pieces as well. Though being matchy-matchy isn‚Äôt the right choice for every couple, planning out looks together prevents any potential clashes and ensures complementary styles‚Äîthis is especially important when you consider how highly photographed all of these events will be. According to Silberstein, you should start by selecting adjectives that best describe your desired aesthetic to help guide your wardrobe choices. For example, ‚ÄúIf the special day is supposed to be fresh, bold, and relaxed, a whimsical floral dress and vibrant suit may be favorable,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBy following this unofficial dress code, the partners guarantee a cohesive, personalized, and special event wardrobe.‚Äù  LaVine also suggests couples adhere to the same level of formality, whether that‚Äôs black-tie or casual, and a similar color scheme. ‚ÄúWhen wearing white to the wedding events, you really want to match your whites down to the tone‚Äîcool white, warm white, or neutral white. And if the bride is in ivory, we definitely don‚Äôt want the groom in white or anything drastically different,‚Äù she explains. "Pastels tend to be more casual, and jewel tones [feel] dressier. Neutrals work both ways, but it depends on the styling.‚Äù Aside from color, the experts go even further to share their top style suggestions for each event, as highlighted below.  For the Engagement Party  There‚Äôs no better way to show off your new relationship status than with an engagement party. Since this is the first of many wedding-related celebrations, LaVine suggests that brides keep their styles relaxed and playful. ‚ÄúI love a fun midi dress for a bride. It‚Äôs somewhere in between sophisticated and fun. Maybe the trim of the skirt has feathers, or the straps have pearls. For styling, you could also go with a fun shoe if your dress leans more simple,‚Äù she says. As for the groom, the stylist recommends going for an equally sophisticated look, like ‚Äúa well-tailored black trouser, nice t-shirt or polo, and a loafer.‚Äù And to tie both looks together, the groom should consider matching his shirt with the color of the bride's dress or shoes.  For the Bridal Shower  Bridal showers are typically daytime events, which means a light color palette, textured fabrics, and romantic silhouettes are all appropriate sartorial choices. Silberstein says, ‚ÄúIf the bride is attending a tea party event hosted by her family and friends, a white long-sleeve lace midi dress with nude ankle strap heels would be an elegant choice.‚Äù In this case, she also recommends advising guests to wear pastel hues to guarantee great photos and a cohesive theme. As for accessories, ‚ÄúThis would be such a special day to wear family heirloom pieces or something of sentimental value. Especially with all of your family around you,‚Äù she adds.  Though a groom‚Äôs appearance may be brief at this event, he should still dress in a complementary outfit. A button-down shirt and dress pants, in a similar color scheme or texture as the bride‚Äôs ensemble, would be perfect for this occasion.  PHOTOS BY KT MERRY AND LAUREN FAIR PHOTOGRAPHY; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  For the Bachelor and Bachelorette Parties  Whether you‚Äôre having a joint celebration or separate events, get creative with your bachelor and bachelorette party ensembles. ‚ÄúThis is such a great time to play around with different styles and types of looks,‚Äù LaVine notes. ‚ÄúFor my brides, I love seeing some different pieces like a blazer dress, a jumpsuit, or a two-piece set. We can get super creative here and have fun.‚Äù She also notes that brides can include at least one statement piece, like "a fun heel wrap-up, feathers, or bows.‚Äù For the groom, LaVine recommends trying out different fabrics, opting for linen pants over jeans, or a leather jacket instead of a blazer. ‚ÄúObviously, grooms don‚Äôt typically try and wear white their whole bachelor trip, but you can still stand out with something fun, like a floral or a chic neutral-on-neutral look,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúCream jeans and a cream t-shirt make for a very versatile outfit that can be worn for any bachelor trip moment.‚Äù  Planning a themed night out? Add some playful corresponding details to your look. For instance, if you‚Äôre hosting a bachelorette weekend in Nashville, Silberstein says, ‚ÄúThe bride can wear a white denim jacket and white denim mini skirt, set along with white cowboy boots to walk down Broadway in style."  For the Welcome Party  If you‚Äôre planning a wedding outside of your city, it‚Äôs common practice to host a welcome party for your guests. And since this is the first time you can really shine a light on your bridal and groom fashions, stick to silhouettes and color palettes that complement your venue or event theme. What's more, LaVine advises couples to embrace a casual dress code, as a welcome party is ‚Äúa raw, stripped-down time to just show the couple and their love.‚Äù  She loves the idea of a bride in a maxi gown paired with a soft beauty look and the groom in a coordinating outfit, which may include a ‚Äúquality khaki or cream pant and white button down, slightly unbuttoned, with a beautiful brown loafer.‚Äù Remember to be mindful of the season, though, as some colder months may call for longer hemlines and thicker fabrics.  For the Rehearsal Dinner  The rehearsal dinner is another opportunity to preview your wedding aesthetics. ‚ÄúThis night is truly connected to the next day, so I like to incorporate small elements of the bridal look into the wedding look,‚Äù LaVine says. ‚ÄúFor example, if your bridal gown has lace on it, it would be really interesting to have a simple gown and add a touch of lace through a glove or long sleeve.‚Äù She also suggests that brides opt for an ‚Äúeffortless, yet put together‚Äù outfit that perfectly blends their bridal status with their personal style. Some elegant options include a floor-length gown, an embellished midi dress, or a satin jumpsuit.  Although the bride commonly wears white on this night, there's no reason why the groom can't consider a more colorful look. Whether that‚Äôs adding a navy jacket on top of a white button-down or donning a jewel-tone suit, the bolder color scheme will make a bride‚Äôs white ensemble pop even more. As for accessories, LaVine says that the groom can keep it simple, opting for no tie, no vest, and leaving the top few buttons of his shirt open for a formal yet relaxed look.  For the Farewell Brunch  After a late night of celebrating their nuptials, many couples will prefer a slightly more casual dress code at their post-wedding brunch. While the attire for this event can vary, you‚Äôll want to prioritize comfort and opt for a look that's functional yet stylish. ‚ÄúFor my brides, I always recommend comfort here! Whether that‚Äôs a chic bridal short and lace top, a jumpsuit, or a silk flow slip dress,‚Äù LaVine says. For the groom, attire suggestions also fall into the relaxed category. She suggests ‚Äúa linen pant and button down, or floral or lace fun shirt with a quality jean‚Äù for a simple look that still feels wedding-worthy.  Additionally, Silberstein recommends that couples ‚Äúbegin their marriage in a matching monochrome color palette.‚Äù White or neutrals are typically the favored option, but consider incorporating a seasonal color into both of your outfits for a statement look that's still cohesive. Jewel-tone hues, like dark purple, burgundy, or forest green, are excellent choices for a fall or winter event, while spring and summer call for pastel colors like light pink, sky blue, or yellow.  PHOTO BY Photo by Julieta; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Styling Tips

Sydney Lotuaco Gets Married and Reveals Her Favorite Moment from Her Wedding Weekend!  Photo credit: Kate Toney  Congrats to the newlyweds!  Bachelor Nation fans got to know Sydney Lotuaco on Season 23 of ‚ÄúThe Bachelor‚Äù and Season 6 of ‚ÄúBachelor in Paradise.‚Äù  Sydney eventually found love off-screen with her now-husband Nick Wehby, and he proposed to her in December 2021.  Now, the couple just officially tied the knot and Sydney took to Instagram to share some special moments from their wedding day.  Sydney first shared photos with her husband and wrote, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never be over it!‚Äù and thanked all of the vendors who helped make their dream wedding day possible.  Waiting for your permission to load TikTok Post.  The Bachelor Nation star shared more photos and said, ‚ÄúI actually don‚Äôt know what to say. I‚Äôd love to come up with something funny to say but I‚Äôm at a loss. Thank you to everyone who made the journey, and even those who couldn‚Äôt, we still felt you.‚Äù  And then Sydney shared one of her favorite moments from her wedding weekend, where she got to wear her mom‚Äôs redesigned wedding dress.  Alongside a video of her in the original dress and the updated version, Sydney wrote, ‚ÄúThis was one of my favorite moments of the weekend and it was only possible because of @macymmeyer who was able to completely redesign my mom‚Äôs wedding dress and give it a second life!! So much love went into this dress and I‚Äôll never forget the look on her face when she first saw it.‚Äù  Waiting for your permission to load TikTok Post.  In the video, both Sydney and her mom were brought to tears by the reveal.  How sweet!  Sydney had previously shared that she planned on using her mom‚Äôs dress to create something she could wear on her wedding weekend.  That video went viral, raking in around 6 million views, and at the time she wrote, ‚ÄúThis was so special. My mom has had her dress preserved in a box for over 30 years and let me take it out to try on to try and utilize for one of my wedding events. It‚Äôs so special and so detailed and took us all back in time! She looked SO beautiful on her day and it‚Äôs surreal to put the same dress on she wore when she married my dad. She gave me her blessing to repurpose it so that I can give it a second life.‚Äù  We absolutely love how the redesigned dress turned out! Check out Sydney‚Äôs full video here.

Some girls around the world dream of their wedding day and plan everything down to the very last detail.  Dottie Fideli was one of those girls and has been dreaming of her ultimate wedding day her entire life.  Now at age 77 she's said 'sod it' to waiting around for a man and has married herself in the ultimate act of self-love at her Ohio retirement home.  Speaking to NBC local affiliate WLWT5, the grandmother revealed she finally had the chance to have the wedding she had always dreamed of.  Advert 10  "This is something I‚Äôve always wanted," she said.  "I wanted to get married and have a happy life but things didn‚Äôt work out that way and now I have a second chance in doing something that‚Äôll make me happy."  Credit: Donna Pennington  "I told my daughter, I said, ‚ÄòThis is the best thing that I‚Äôve ever had, outside of having you kids'," told the Today show.  Advert 10  Ms Fideli had been married once before, back in 1965.  But the ill-fated nuptials were never meant to be.  After she and her ex-husband exchanged vows at a courthouse, 'he went to work and I went home'.  "I wore a black dress, so I was doomed before I got started," she revealed.  Advert 10  But she had always dreamed of having her own 'big wedding', but was dismayed at the idea it was 'too late' for her.  Her daughter, Donna Pennington, was determined to make her mother's dreams come true.  They set about decorating the community room of O‚ÄôBannon Terrace Retirement Home in Goshen, Ohio, with balloons and her daughter cooked all of the food.  Family, friends, and loved ones turned out to see Fideli in her dream white dress with sheer long sleeves and a silver belt.  Advert 10  She also wore a white veil with an embellished headband.  Credit: Donna Pennington  Like any blushing bride, Fideli was 'nervous' leading up to the big day.  But, when the sun set on her dream wedding day, she ended up 'really happy' after marrying herself.  Advert 10  In her hand as she said her vows to herself, she held a white lily as a symbol for self-love.  "I said, 'Everybody takes this outside lily. And they live their life and they think they‚Äôre happy and everything‚Äôs going to be hunky-dory, but they don‚Äôt consider the inside, the little petals inside'," she told Today.  "The inside is what‚Äôs important. That‚Äôs where God‚Äôs love flows. That‚Äôs where he gives you wisdom and he gives you hope. And nobody ever takes time to think about that."  She added: "So that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve done, and I‚Äôd appreciate it if all of you people would do it and think of it that way."  Good for you, Dottie.

Your dress is tailored, your hair and makeup trial is complete, and you‚Äôve also lined up all the vendors, paid the deposits, and sent every invite. With all of the major to-dos checked off your list, you may be wondering what's left to be done. While floral arrangements and seating charts may be top of mind, don‚Äôt forget about the reason this all began in the first place: your engagement ring! Prepping your wedding jewelry‚Äîyour engagement ring and both wedding bands‚Äîis an important but often overlooked step in the getting-ready process; just as you were diligent about ensuring that your diamond or colorful gemstone looked its best in your engagement photos, you should extend that same level of care for your jewelry in the days before you say ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are likely many wedding guests who will see your rings for the first time on your wedding day so they need to be on point,‚Äù shares Sharon Schatner, GIA Diamond Graduate at Filigree Jewelers. ‚ÄúAnd let‚Äôs not forget about your wedding pictures. Your rings will be highlighted in those forever photos so they need to look perfect.‚Äù  Meet the Expert Easter Ahn-Lee is a fine jewelry and engagement ring designer, and the founder of the jewelry brand Easter Ahn Design.  Sharon Schatner is a GIA diamond graduate and self-proclaimed "rock nerd" at Filigree Jewelers in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  That's why it's so important to properly care for your special pieces ahead of the big day. To take the guesswork out of caring for your wedding jewelry‚Äîand ensuring they're in the best possible condition on the day you say "I do"‚Äîwe created a timeline that outlines exactly what you need to do and when, from the moment you get engaged to the day you tie the knot. Follow the expert advice of Schatner and Easter Ahn-Lee, a fine jewelry and engagement ring designer, and your rings will be ready for their wedding debut.  Photo by Valorie Darling; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  As Soon as Possible: Get Your Ring Resized  Before we dive into the specifics, if your wedding rings don't fit your finger the way you'd like, be sure to have them resized as soon as possible. ‚ÄúI would recommend having your ring resized right away, whether it's too big or small,‚Äù says Ahn-Lee. What's more, while weight loss shouldn't be a priority on your to-do list, Ahn-Lee further notes that ‚Äúfor couples who lose weight before the wedding day, I would recommend resizing the wedding bands to fit a few weeks before the wedding day so there isn't a significant change to ring size.‚Äù  One Year Out: Establish Your Budget  When establishing a comprehensive wedding budget, make sure you account for your wedding bands‚Äîwhile they're not as pricey of a line item as catering, for example, knowing how much you have to spend allows you to better consider your options. ‚ÄúYour wedding jewelry is usually part of your wedding budget, so it is also helpful to know how much you plan on spending,‚Äù explains Ahn-Lee. ‚ÄúYou'll also need time to research and plan your [pieces] if you are doing any custom jewelry work.‚Äù Start saving photos of ring stacks and individual bands you like in order to share them with your partner and jeweler when shopping.  Planning on wearing earrings, a bracelet, or a necklace alongside your bands? Consider whether you want to purchase those items, or if you‚Äôre borrowing them from family members, and include that in your budget. And if those borrowed items need to be cleaned, bring them along on your next trip to the jeweler.  Six Months Out: Take Your Engagement Ring in for a Checkup  About six months before you say "I do," visit your jeweler for a quick ring checkup. This is also a great time to ask questions about how to best care for your rock while at home. ‚ÄúGeneral knowledge on how to care for and protect your jewelry will help maintain its beauty,‚Äù says Ahn-Lee. Lastly, while we highly recommend this step ahead of the wedding, you should continue to get your ring examined on a regular basis and add it to your routine for years to come. ‚ÄúA half-yearly to yearly checkup is also recommended to ensure the stones are secure and prongs, links, clasps, and settings are in good condition," Ahn-Lee adds.    Photo by Rachel Rodgers Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Three to Four Months Out: Buy Your Wedding Bands  It's generally recommended that you choose your wedding bands at least three to four months before the wedding, and Schatner adds that couples should buy their bands no later than one month before the big day. When selecting your bands, make it a day-long event with your partner and schedule time to grab breakfast or lunch, then head to the jeweler to try on those all-important pieces. As for who picks up the tab for the rings? That all depends! If you want to purchase your partner‚Äôs band and they yours, that's great, but it‚Äôs certainly not a requirement. ‚ÄúSince wedding bands are generally part of the wedding budget, the couple can discuss how they want to purchase them,‚Äù explains Ahn-Lee. ‚ÄúThere is no right or wrong way on who should be buying them.‚Äù  Finally, once your rings are ready, Schatner advises couples to pick them up together so the jeweler can make sure they're a perfect fit. ‚ÄúIf an alteration needs to be made, you can leave it with the jeweler, saving yourself time and an extra trip.‚Äù  About a Week Out: Get Your Rings Cleaned  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs ideal to get your rings cleaned as close to the day of the wedding as possible, so they are at their sparkling best for your special day,‚Äù says Schatner. ‚ÄúYour jeweler is happy to clean your rings for you, and when we clean them we also check for loose stones or lifted prongs.‚Äù If you're having them cleaned a week out, you may want to store your jewelry in a ring box rather than wear it; if going a week without your precious rock feels unimaginable, be sure to remove it whenever cooking, cleaning, working out, or applying makeup, sunscreen, or moisturizer, thus ensuring it remains clean and shiny ahead of the wedding. If you're nervous about keeping it pristine, see if your jeweler can send you home with a convenient cleaning pen for on-the-spot touchups or else try to squeeze in a cleaning appointment closer to the wedding date.  Photo by Leah Marie Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  What to Avoid  In the lead-up to your wedding day, it's important to be extra careful with your jewelry, and when in doubt, take it off. ‚ÄúTo protect their jewelry and reduce the risk of damage before the wedding day, a couple should avoid impact on hard surfaces, gripping items with force, or applying strong pressure to jewelry or hands when jewelry is worn, such as when working out or performing physical labor,‚Äù shares Ahn-Lee. ‚ÄúAvoid harsh chemicals such as chlorine and household bleach and everyday substances such as lotion, hairspray, and perfume.‚Äù  If you‚Äôre concerned about potentially damaging your band or stone before the big day, consider taking your ring off as soon as you get home. Keep a small dish near the sink so you remember to remove it when washing dishes, and designate a spot in the bathroom and bedroom so your precious jewels are in a secure place when you‚Äôre not wearing them.

Expand Autoplay Image 1 of 5 Cappella Romana‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Ukrainian Wedding‚Äù Ukrainian weddings feature decorated tree branches. (Photo by Nadia Tarnawsky/Photo by Nadia Tarnawsky)  The war in Ukraine has made its culture more precious than ever, especially traditions that might become lost after the smoke clears. One of Ukraine‚Äôs unique cultural gems involves the music and customs that accompany a traditional wedding. You can hear these evocative songs in ‚ÄúA Ukrainian Wedding,‚Äù which will be performed by the women of Cappella Romana with guest Ukrainian singers.  The program is curated by Nadia Tarnawsky, a professional singer and folklorist who gives workshops on Ukrainian music throughout the nation.  ‚ÄúI grew up speaking Ukrainian as a first language,‚Äù said Tarnawsky, ‚ÄúMy father came to Cleveland, Ohio during World War II, and my mother was born in the U.S. Her family came here from Ukraine in the late Nineteenth Century with the first wave of immigrants.‚Äù  HERE IS OREGON: HereisOregon.com | Instagram | YouTube | Facebook | Twitter | TikTok  Tarnawsky has a bachelors in music education from Case Western Reserve University, where she has also pursued a masters in ethnomusicology. From 2017 to 2018, she spent 10 months in Ukraine on a Fulbright Scholarship to study its folk music and traditions.  During that time, Tarnawsky traveled with Inna Kovtun, artistic director of the Kyiv-based ensemble Rozhanytsia, to villages where they learned and recorded songs. Since the war started in Ukraine last year, Kovtun has moved to Portland with her daughter. Her husband remains in Ukraine.  ‚ÄúIt is important to get these songs,‚Äù said Kovtun. ‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt that many people who remember all of the verses. Now there are even fewer people because of the war. Nadia and I just listened to them. These are old songs, but I can learn the melody after hearing it one time. The music speaks to my soul.‚Äù  Because most of the wedding music is sung by the women of the villages, the concert will feature the women of Cappella Romana plus Tarnawsky, Kovtun, and Hanna Tischenko, who is also a professional folk singer from Ukraine now living as a refugee in Chicago.  The Cappella Romana program draws from wedding folk songs that are not from a particular region of Ukraine, but from all around the country.  ‚ÄúIn general, wedding music has specific songs that happen at specific times,‚Äù said Tarnawsky. ‚ÄúWhen the matchmakers come to your house, there‚Äôs a song that you sing. When you make the wedding bread called the korovai. It is a yeasty bread, and they did it on ‚ÄòThe Great British Baking Show.‚Äô You sing about what goes in the bread and how you make it. There are songs about dressing the bride and groom. There is a song about the girl on her last night as an unmarried woman. Songs about making the wreaths that go on their heads. Songs about what to expect when the bride moves into the man‚Äôs household, which meant living with the mother-in-law and father-in-law.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWeddings are held on Sundays,‚Äù added Tarnawsky. ‚ÄúOn Mondays the bride‚Äôs friends would have farewell breakfast with her and sing these lamentations. There would be songs about how she is not a member of their group anymore. Sometimes she would have to leave the village, and they wouldn‚Äôt see her again.‚Äù  The second half of the program features music that is usually sung during the wedding ceremony.  ‚ÄúAlthough the church wedding music is not exactly folk in style,‚Äù explained Tarnawsky, ‚ÄúI opted to use compositions from composers who were inspired by folk traditions, along with widely known Kyivan chant versions, and pieces which use the liturgical tones. They will be in a more standard, Slavic style.‚Äù  Tarnawsky also mentioned that there are other songs that are sung after the wedding, but those songs won‚Äôt be part of the concert.  ‚ÄúSome songs have a lot of double-entendre meanings and are racy,‚Äù explained Tarnawsky, ‚ÄúAnd there are a number of songs that remind me of Appalachian murder ballads. They are kind of dark in a similar way.‚Äù  But she did talk about one folk song that is done at every wedding.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a song about two doves that love each other very much,‚Äù said Tarnawsky. ‚ÄúThey have a nest on the side of a mountain. An eagle comes in and kills the male dove and scoops up the female. He takes the female home where he has a whole bunch of doves in cages. He gives her plenty of food and water, but she is unhappy. She just wants to weep and return to the mountain to the place where she was with the male dove. He offers her other male doves, but she rejects them, complaining that their down is not right, and they don‚Äôt have the right voice when they coo.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI thought that it was a depressing song,‚Äù continued Tarnawsky, ‚Äúand I asked why is it sung as part of a wedding. A sweet grandmother replied ‚ÄòLook at how true her love is. She will love him forever even when he is no longer there. Why wouldn‚Äôt you sing this at a wedding.‚Äô‚Äù  That song, unfortunately, has even more meaning in light of the current situation in Ukraine.  8 p.m. Saturday, May 20, St. Mary‚Äôs Cathedral, 1739 N.W. Couch St., Portland; and at 3 p.m. Sunday, May 21, Christ the King Parish, 11709 S.E. Fuller Road, Milwaukie; $5-$53, cappellaromana.org.  -- James Bash

The Jordanian royal family has already had a busy year of celebrating, with Queen Rania and King Abdullah II‚Äôs oldest daughter, Princess Iman, marrying Jameel Thermiotis on March 12, 2023. Now, the group is preparing for another royal wedding: Crown Prince Hussein‚Äôs nuptials to Rajwa Al-Saif, which is expected to take place on June 1, 2023. In the latest update on May 15, 2023, The Royal Watcher blogger Saad Salman revealed the expected wedding dress code, and it appears to ditch one key accessory that epitomizes royalty. When a fan asked about the attire for the affair via Twitter, Salman responded, ‚ÄúMore like black tie, long dress but no tiaras.‚Äù The royal blogger never clarified whether the ‚Äúno tiara‚Äù rule applies to the bride, however.  Handout / Getty Images  The Twitter thread began with Salman confirming that Queen Azizah of Malaysia and her husband, King Abdullah, will attend the crown prince‚Äôs wedding. Many other royals around the world will also make an appearance. According to Hello!, the guest list will include Princess Hisakoa and Princess Tsuguko of Japan, Crown Prince Frederik and Crown Princess Mary of Denmark, Crown Princess Victoria and Prince Daniel of Sweden, and Crown Prince Haakon of Norway.  On May 14, 2023, the Royal Hashemite Court revealed the official logo for Hussein‚Äôs big day, which is an Arabic symbol topped with a crown. ‚ÄúAs the date of the wedding of HRH Crown Prince Al Hussein and Miss Rajwa Khalid Alseif nears, we are pleased to share the official logo to mark the occasion, which is Arabic for ‚Äòwe rejoice,‚Äô‚Äù the court tweeted, along with a clip of the graphic. The post even mentioned a hashtag for the special day, which is #CelebratingAlHussein.  The Royal Hashemite Court first announced the crown prince‚Äôs wedding date back in December of 2022, but the entity has kept many of the other details a secret. "The Royal Hashemite Court is pleased to announce that the wedding of His Royal Highness Crown Prince Al Hussein bin Abdullah II and Miss Rajwa Khalid Al Saif will take place on June 1, 2023,‚Äù the court released in a statement. ‚ÄúThe Royal Hashemite Court extends its sincere congratulations to Their Majesties King Abdullah II and Queen Rania Al Abdullah on this occasion and wishes His Royal Highness Crown Prince Al Hussein bun Abdullah II and Miss Raja Khalid Al Said a lifetime of happiness #Jordan.‚Äù  To share the news, the royal court shared a photo of the couple posing together, with the bride-to-be in a white dress with puff sleeves and the future groom in a dark suit. The day is a special one for the future newlyweds because Hussein‚Äôs parents, Queen Rania and King Abdullah II, will celebrate their 30th wedding anniversary a little over a week later, on June 10, 2023, Tatler reports.  The couple first announced their engagement on August 18, 2022. ‚ÄúWe pray that God grants us His blessings,‚Äù Hussein wrote on his Instagram account. ‚ÄúGrateful to my dear Jordanian family for their heartfelt support and kind wishes.‚Äù The future king of Jordan also uploaded a snap of himself and his soon-to-be wife, and her diamond ring is on full display in the photo. According to Tatler, Hussein popped the question at Rajwa‚Äôs father‚Äôs home, and his parents were also present to witness the proposal. Queen Rania commented on the Instagram post, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think it was possible to hold so much joy in my heart! Congratulations to my eldest Prince Hussein and his beautiful bride-to-be, Rajwa.‚Äù

Who: Laura (Weinel) and Austin Whalen  When: July 30, 2022  The story: The Whalens were both environmental science students attending Miami University in 2012, but they didn‚Äôt meet in Oxford, Ohio. They were most of a continent away in the Bahamas, thanks to the university‚Äôs marine ecology program, studying sea stars. The proposal eight years later happened in an altogether different climate, though: on a mountaintop in Colorado.  The details: ‚ÄúAustin and I care very deeply about the natural world, so it was incredibly important to us that our wedding paid homage to nature,‚Äù Laura says. ‚ÄúBefore our public ceremony, we hiked the trails on our venue's property‚Äîme, barefoot, of course‚Äîjust the two of us and our photographer. About a half-mile back in the woods is a gorgeous waterfall, where we had a private vow reading ceremony. It was so special and intimate and beautiful.‚Äù She describes their wedding as an earthy, wildflower party in the woods. To that end, guests took home wildflower seed packets from American Meadows as their favors.  Of note: All of the key songs of the day were by musicians that the couple had seen live. This included Billy Strings‚Äô ‚ÄúLove Like Me‚Äù and Trampled By Turtles‚Äô ‚ÄúAlone‚Äù (processional), ‚ÄúSee the World‚Äù by Caamp (recessional) and ‚ÄúThe Mountain Song‚Äù by Rayland Baxter (first dance).  Vendors  Photographer: Jenna Knott Photo  Planner: JKR Events  Ceremony and reception: Crockett‚Äôs Run  Caterer: The Berwick, Pizza Crossing  Bar service:Sunshine Wine Mobile Bar  Cake: Sadie Baby Sweets, Ditch the Mix  Florist:Hoku Floral  Rentals: Bedrock Party Rentals, Party Plus Lancaster, United Rentals  Music: Andy Shaw Band  Stationery: Zazzle, Skip to My Lou Design on Etsy  Accommodations and rehearsal dinner: Crockett‚Äôs Run  Sunday brunch: Crockett‚Äôs Run, catered by Buckeye Donuts  Bride‚Äôs attire: Grace Loves Lace gown and veil, accessories from Etsy and Stone & Solder  Bride‚Äôs hair and makeup: 614 Beauty  Groom‚Äôs attire: Suit from the Black Tux  Rings: Doron Merav, SilverJewellerySpot on Etsy  Bridesmaids‚Äô attire: Azazie gowns  Flower girls‚Äô and ring bearers‚Äô attire: Amazon  Groomsmen‚Äôs attire: Suits from the Black Tux

A wedding photographer‚Äôs quick thinking prevented a disaster after a bride‚Äôs huge diamond ring went missing.  Laura Palacios was shooting the couple‚Äôs big day and toward the end, the bride and groom wanted to jump into the pool. About five minutes after, Palacios noticed people searching the pool floor.  ‚ÄúI asked, ‚ÄòDid you lose something?‚Äô My gut was saying it was the ring,‚Äù Palacios tells Newsweek. ‚ÄúThe bride, Courtney, put her hand on the side of the pool for me to see. The ring was there. The diamond was gone. She was as calm and happy as she had been all day.‚Äù  Despite the bride‚Äôs calmness over the situation, wedding guests were frantically searching for the missing gem ‚Äî that‚Äôs when Palacios had her brilliant idea.  ‚ÄúI looked back through images and realized it had gone missing at some point on the dance floor,‚Äù says the wedding shooter.  Her ingenuity meant that the group quickly ascertained they were looking in the wrong place, Palacios‚Äôs pictures confirmed that the diamond had gone missing long before the couple jumped in the pool.  ‚ÄúI would have jumped in the pool to help them look, but I wanted to be sure we weren‚Äôt wasting time looking in the wrong place,‚Äù adds Palacios.  The dance floor actually had wooden slats but amazingly the diamond was so big that it had become wedged in a gap.  ‚ÄúIt was a miracle,‚Äù Palacios adds. She posted another video of the moment the precious jewel was recovered by a staff member who returned it to the grateful bride and groom.  More of Palacios‚Äôs work can be viewed on her website, TikTok, Facebook, and Instagram.  Image credits: All photos by Laura Palacios.

Kelsie Connelly is a South Carolina based event planner and social media manager. She studied theatre in college, and went on to open Love Elise Events in 2022. Her work has been published in Wedding Chicks, and she spends every day dreaming up the next big thing on her docket. In her down time, you can spot her with her husband, friends, and four German Shepherds at a local brewery or brunch stop where they‚Äôre most likely working on their next project together.

Janet Towers with her son John and new daughter-in-law Sarah-jane (Image: Deep South Media)  A CARE home resident unable to attend her son‚Äôs wedding was left astonished when the ceremony was brought to her.  Janet Towers, a resident of Colten Care‚Äôs Belmore Lodge in Lymington, is no longer able to travel.  Her greatest wish recently had been to see her son John get married to his partner Sarah-Jane.  The New Forest care home secretly transformed Janet‚Äôs room into a beautiful wedding chapel ‚Äì enabling her to see her son exchange vows with his fianc√©e.  Janie Wilkins, home manager of Belmore Lodge said: ‚ÄúWhen we learned that Janet may have to miss the wedding, we knew that simply wouldn‚Äôt do.  ‚ÄúSo, we told a little fib and asked Janet if we could dress her room for a marketing promotion, to show how we can accommodate special occasions.  ‚ÄúJanet agreed and this gave us the opportunity to transform her room and of course dress her accordingly as the beautiful mother of the groom.  ‚ÄúOne significant detail was left out though, and that was that we would be re-creating John‚Äôs upcoming wedding.‚Äù  Bournemouth Echo: Janet Towers with her son John.  Janet Towers with her son John. (Image: Deep South Media)  Her room was adorned with flowers and had a wedding arch.  ‚ÄúJust before the ‚Äòphotoshoot‚Äô I told Janet we had a surprise and gave her the order of service for John‚Äôs wedding,‚Äù continued Janie.  ‚ÄúShe said, ‚Äòbut I can‚Äôt go‚Äô, and I said, ‚Äòno, so they are coming to you‚Äô.  ‚ÄúWhen John and Sarah-Jane came into the room, with Sarah-Jane‚Äôs two sons Joshua and Gabriel, everyone was so overwhelmed and emotional.‚Äù  The couple went on to read the same vows they would say in the ceremony and exchanged rings.  Everyone then enjoyed cake and toasted the newlyweds with pink fizz.  An emotional Janet said: ‚ÄúI had no idea this was going to happen, but I can‚Äôt thank everyone enough.  ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think I would be able to be part of John and Sarah-Jane‚Äôs wedding, but I was, and I loved every single moment of it. Thank you so much to everyone who made my wish possible.‚Äù  Janet‚Äôs son John added: ‚ÄúMy wife and I are extremely grateful to Janie and all the staff at Belmore Lodge who made our special day so memorable. To have mum at our wedding was truly the icing on the cake.‚Äù

Choosing your wedding hairstyle is a task that seems like it should be simple, but most brides-to-be would agree that it can be surprisingly difficult to navigate. After all, this is going to be one of the most photographed days of your entire life, so your final look will be on full display for years to come. In addition to considering which type of hairstyle will best suit your wedding style, location, and dress, you'll also need to think about how you envision yourself as bride: Do you want your hair styled into soft, romantic waves that skim across your back, or do you prefer the look of a polish, elegant updo?  As it turns out, you don't need to choose just one hairstyle for your big day. According to hairstylist Jill Buck, the creative behind Hayley Erbert's two stunning cover story hairstyles, a mid-party swap is not only entirely feasible, but it's actually easy to achieve if your pro has prepped your hair properly. Here, she shares her tips for long-lasting nuptial hairstyles and advice on how to change up your look during the wedding.  For soft waves that last all day, start with the right base.  Buck stresses the importance of ensuring that your hairdresser has enough time to prep your hair; ask how long they'd need in an ideal world and build your morning-of timeline around that. "For brides, I like to really take time in the prep of the hair. It needs to last all day and often there isn‚Äôt time to reset any curls on such a busy day," she says. "I start on wet hair with Joico‚Äôs K-Pak Luster Lock Spray (for heat protection) and then Joi Whip Design Foam (for structure and hold)." Then, she gives the hair a "nice, full blowout" and curls the entire head using a 1 1/4" curling iron (Buck likes the T3 Micro). "Using the bigger iron helps the waves to be a little softer than a traditional Hollywood glam look," she explains.  Hayley's soft waves require two additional steps: For that soft, touchable look, Buck says she finishes the curls with a Mason Pierson boar bristle brush and locks the shape in place with Joico‚Äôs JoiMist hairspray.    Be sure to choose your most flattering side for a part.  If there's one piece of advice Buck wants to give all brides-to-be, it's that you should over-communicate your preferred "side" so that your stylist can part your hair accordingly. "There is nothing more frustrating than setting a look only to find you have to switch the part!" she says. Plus, you wouldn't want to end up with a hairstyle that doesn't feel like "you," and parting your hair in a way you've never done before almost always ends in that result.  And don't forget to consider what best suits your wedding dress.  Another pro tip from Buck? During your hair trial, be sure to show your hairstylist a photo of your wedding dress. "The dress neckline is always my starting point, too," she explains. "You don‚Äôt want the hair and dress in competition; they should complement one another."  If the hair was properly set, changing to an updo should be a breeze.  The beauty of Buck's method? Taking the hair from soft, flowing waves into a structured updo is an extremely straightforward process. "After my initial set the hair is in perfect condition to put into an updo. I don‚Äôt like to use an iron after hairspray so your brush is going to be the best tool for changing the shape," she explains. How did she bring Hayley's look up in a flash? "On a sleek center part I brushed her hair into two ponytails one on top of the other. This helps give me control of how sleek I can get it as well as a good anchor to set the updo and place the Bobby pins. Mini rubber bands, different Bobby pin sizes, and firm hairspray are all good tools to have."  And if you want to go the other direction? Just be clear about your plans during your first hair trial. It's certainly not impossible to go from an updo to a long, loose hairstyle, but you'll likely need to do some touchups once pins and rubber bands come out, and your stylist may want to use a softer, more flexible hairspray on your initial updo than they otherwise would.  Decide if going from hair down to an updo‚Äîor vice versa‚Äîmakes the most sense for your day.  According to Buck, brides tend to choose updos for more formal events or for the more traditional portion of the day, so most women prefer to star with their hair up and then bring it down. That being said, there's a real benefit to going in the other direction: By the time the party starts and you're ready to dance, having your hair up and out of your face might be exactly what you want. You'll have taken your beautiful portraits with long, flowing hair, and now you can stay cool and look fresh throughout the party.

EW exclusively debuts a season 4 finale moment with Rafael Silva and Ronen Rubinstein that was left on the cutting room floor.  9-1-1: Lone Star deleted scene: Carlos and TK cut their wedding cake ‚Äî and do exactly what you expect  9-1-1: Lone Star just had too much of a good thing.  The team behind the Fox first responder drama filmed so many Tarlos wedding scenes that some had to be left out of the final cut of Tuesday's two-hour season 4 finale. But now one of those moments is seeing the light of day, with EW exclusively revealing TK (Ronen Rubinstein) and Carlos (Rafael Silva) cutting their wedding cake.  "I want a divorce!" TK ends the clip, after Carlos smooshes a slice all over his face. "An annulment's cheaper," Carlos' ex-wife, Iris (Lyndsy Fonseca), chimes in from the sidelines.  But despite all the sorrow throughout the finale, Silva says filming the wedding "felt like bliss, it felt like joy, and it felt like love. Everyone was in happy mode. It's a wedding, and we have the entire cast there, so it's a f---ing blast. Everyone's loud, everyone's laughing, and it's a lot of fun."  "It was a celebration of also wrapping the season," adds Rubinstein, "closing another chapter on this tremendous journey that we're on. It was a beautiful culmination."  Now looking forward to season 5, the two actors have a few ideas on where their characters go from here now that they're married. Silva is excited to explore what Gabriel's death does to Carlos, while Rubinstein hopes to see his character interact more with his "firehouse mom," Tommy (Gina Torres). They also have some ideas about Tarlos' home life...  "I'm also excited to see who Carlos is as a husband," says Silva. "I'm also excited to see if TK knocks on Carlos' door and is like, "Hey, you ready to have a kid yet? Can we talk about this?"  "I echo that!" adds Rubinstein. An Orange County woman is desperately searching for the return of her beloved wedding dress that was accidentally donated to a local Goodwill.  Rebecca Nguyen Sanchez/Facebook  Rebecca Nguyen was wearing a beautiful classic lace gown adorned with beading and spaghetti straps when she married the love of her life in August 2017. In the years since, the dress has acted as a reminder of the magical day.  "When I wore it, I felt like me," Nguyen said. "I want to say I felt like this movie star. I felt like this princess, but that wasn't me. I felt like me."  The memories of that dream quickly turned into a nightmare on Tuesday, when she received the shock of her life, learning that her dress was suddenly missing.  "My wedding dress was accidentally donated by one of my family members. It was a complete accident, it was during a rush of a lot of things," she said while speaking with KCAL News on Wednesday. "Mistakes happen. When I found out yesterday I was pretty heartbroken."  Nguyen says that the dress wasn't the only wedding souvenir that got donated to a Goodwill in Brea more than two weeks ago, and she immediately submitted an accidental donation form in hopes of retrieving what she could.  She's visited Goodwill's Orange County headquarters, hoping that some of the employees could help her recover the lost items.  "It could be sitting at the warehouse, still waiting to get sorted through," said Chris Sewitsky, the retail director at the location. "It just depends where and what time of day it came in. That store is a very busy store. Some stuff does stay at that store, some stuff comes back to main distribution. So, we're hoping we can find it because it is such a unique item."  On top of her local search, Nguyen has also posted on several local Facebook pages offering to buy back the dress if it's already been purchased.  "If you have it, please consider selling it back to me. I will pay more than you paid for it. You can even wear it for your wedding! I don't mind sharing the joy and beauty of the dress," one post says.  If someone does have it, she's hopeful that they're able to get as much enjoyment out of their special day as she did.  "Not everybody can afford to get a brand new dress and that's okay. I want someone to be able to enjoy it as well," Nguyen said.  Anyone with more information on the missing dress can reach out to Goodwill in Brea, which is located at 634 S. Brea Boulevard, by calling (714) 255-1099.

As you're planning your wedding, you likely want to craft a celebration that you'll love looking back on for years to come. The best way to organize a timeless event is to host classic affair with plenty of design details that have already proven they can stand the test of time. "Picking wedding d√©cor and fashion can be daunting, especially if you want your wedding to feel timeless," shares wedding planner Dani Blasena of HauteF√™tes. "While Instagram and Pinterest are wonderful for inspiration, they often promote the same trending ideas over and over again. In contrast, a timeless wedding is one that stands the test of time and style!" So, if you want to plan a timeless ceremony and reception, it's best to choose color palettes, fashion, and d√©cor that will still feel relevant in 20 years.  It's important to remember that timeless weddings can take many forms, so don't shy away from the style out of fear of planning a cookie cutter celebration. You can still infuse the day with plenty of personality. "For me, what makes a wedding timeless is not about following the most current wedding trends or guidelines but about creating a celebration that genuinely reflects a couple's unique love story and values," notes wedding photographer Jenny Fu. "It's about making an impact that lasts long after the day."  Meet the Expert Dani Blasena is the owner, creative director and lead designer of HauteF√™tes.  Jenny Fu is a New York-based wedding photographer.  Jacqueline Hallgarth is the founder of wedding and event planning company Jacqueline Hallgarth Events.  If you're hoping to plan a timeless wedding that feels right for you and your spouse-to-be, we asked wedding pros to share their favorite details. Ahead, 20 ideas you can make your own.  Photo by KT Merry; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Choose a Classic Destination  ‚ÄúVenue selection is one of the most important aspects of creating a timeless wedding,‚Äù shares planner Jacqueline Hallgarth. If you know you want to tie the knot far from home, consider a locale that's steeped in history. ‚ÄúYou and your guests will be linked forever through this selection, so choose carefully," she adds. "A destination wedding, held in historic villa in Italy or chateau in France, will not only be beautiful on your wedding day, but will also create timeless memories shared by you and all your guests. Regardless of the specific venue, beautiful memories can be created anywhere with the right elements.‚Äù  Photo by Caroline Tran; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Pick an Estate-Style Venue  Modern art galleries and open warehouses are incredible blank slates, but they're not the best choices for timeless celebrations. ‚ÄúChoosing an estate-style venue that is classic in architecture and will create a backdrop for your big day that is as relevant in 20 years‚Äô time as it is today,‚Äù advises Blasena. ‚ÄúMy favorites include Rosewood Miramar Beach for a classic Hamptons style on the West Coast replete with boxwoods and white siding. Abroad, the Belmond San Michele with views for days, classic Italian-style spaces and gardens that are breathtaking. Both venues have everything you need to make your big day truly timeless from start to finish.‚Äù  Photo by Will Reid Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have a Black-Tie Dress Code  What your guests wear will have an impact on the overall feel of your celebration, so picking the right attire style is important. ‚ÄúBy requesting black-tie and formal attire, you automatically create an elevated style that translates into forever cherished photographs,‚Äù shares Hallgarth. "Floor-length gowns and black tuxedos never go out of fashion and when captured together, creates that timeless look everyone wants from their wedding.‚Äù  Photo by Volvoreta; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Choose Greenery and White Florals  When picking out your floral design, you can never go wrong with classic white blooms and lots of lush greenery. Blasena says, ‚ÄúGreen and white flowers are both classic and neutral and will never overwhelm a design.‚Äù  Photo by Stephanie Sunderland; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Embrace a Soft Color Palette  Punchy colors might be trending, but are you sure you'll love Barbie pink or neon green for years to come? If the answer isn't a resounding "yes!" it's likely not the best choice. ‚ÄúA soft color palette is always a good rule of thumb," notes Blasena. "Something like a French blue or classic taupe is always sophisticated and elegant. Pick two to three soft colors that suit your style best and keep it simple.‚Äù  Photo by Ryan Ray; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Hire the Right Wedding Photographer  You could plan a big day that's entirely timeless, but if you hire a photographer with a trendy, of-the-moment aesthetic, your photos might not stand the test of time. "To truly capture the timeless essence of a wedding, it's crucial to work with an experienced photographer who can document your day,‚Äù shares Fu. ‚ÄúThe photographs they capture will be a lasting reminder of the love and joy you shared on your wedding day.‚Äù Blasena adds, ‚ÄúA photographer with a classic editing style, natural color tones, and graceful composition will create photographs never go out of style.‚Äù  Photo by Lev Kuperman; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  And Don't Shy Away from Candid Photos  While traditional wedding portraits are essential, some couples avoid candids out of fear of looking too modern. Whatever you do, get this idea out of your head. "Candid wedding photographs have the power to capture the true essence and emotion of your wedding day," says Fu. "Let the genuine connections and meaningful moments shine‚Äìthese moments are timeless because you've lived the experience, and the candid photographs can take you back long after the day has passed."  Photo by Henry + Mac; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Wear Classic Wedding Attire  Fashion trends come and go, even in the world of weddings. ‚ÄúOne of the most important elements of your wedding is your dress,‚Äù says Blasena. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to get caught up in all the amazing wedding fashion there is today with designers from all over the world. To avoid looking back in horror, think timeless and classic in the cut; a soft ivory versus a stark white; and, avoid overcomplicating the style with unnecessary embellishments such as beading, tulle, or lace. Remember, less is always more!‚Äù  Photo by Lisa Poggi; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have Musicians at Your Ceremony  Acoustic versions of your favorite romantic songs can bring an emotional elegance and set the proper tone for your wedding ceremony. Consider hiring a string trio or a classical guitarist to play as you walk down the aisle.  Photo by Benjamin Wheeler and Ben Higgins; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Close Out the Ceremony With a Flower Petal Toss  Add an extra dose of joy and ensure excellent photos of your ceremony exit by having guests toss flower petals over your heads as you recess down the aisle as newlyweds.  Photo By Twah Dougherty; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Decorate With Chinoiserie  A classic d√©cor choice for a wedding is to bring chinoiserie ceramics into your design. Used as vessels for your florals or in your dinnerware, it adds a traditional and elegant touch to the space.  Photo by Haley Rynn Ringo; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have a Champagne Tower  Serving Champagne is a classic choice for a wedding. Serve your favorite bubbly in coupes, stacked in a tower, to make for an extra celebratory (and photo-worthy) moment at your reception.  Photo by AGP Collective; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Set Up a Checkered Dance Floor  A checkered dance floor is a classic for a reason. It sets the tone for the reception and brings a retro elegance as you get down with your new spouse and guests.  Photo by Corbin Gurkin; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Embrace Candlelight  ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs dinner for two or a wedding for 250, candlelight creates an intimate atmosphere which can transform any space,‚Äù shares Blasena. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing more magical than a candlelit room to create romance. Adding clusters of pillar and votive candles or simple white taper candles to your tabletop is an inexpensive touch that will also never go out of style.‚Äù  Photo by An√©e Atelier; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Opt for Black-and-White Photos  Don‚Äôt forget to ask your photographer to edit some shots without color. ‚ÄúBlack and white photography is classic, timeless, and elegant. It creates a sophisticated look that will never go out of style,‚Äù says Fu.  Photo by Jenny Fu; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Consider Seasonal Shades  ‚ÄúFeaturing seasonal colors in the floral, stationery, tabletop and event design creates an event that resonates with guests emotions and ties your wedding to a place in time,‚Äù shares Hallgarth. "I always encourage bright and colorful blooms for a spring wedding and autumnal florals and foliage for a fall wedding which captures not only the beauty of the moment, but forever marries the event to a specific feeling of the year.‚Äù  Photo by Brooke Miller Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have a Getaway Car  After you say ‚ÄúI do,‚Äù there‚Äôs nothing more timeless than speeding off into the sunset with your new spouse. Find a vintage car and adorn it with florals for a charming getaway for the newlyweds as they head to the reception.  Photo by Sasithon Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Make a Grand Entrance  As the wedding reception begins, have a special moment where the emcee announces the bride and groom for the first time as they rush out onto the dance floor. The entrance is a fun and celebratory moment that can easily transition to the first dance, and it's something that's been done at weddings for decades.  Photo by Allan Zepeda Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Hire a Live Band  While choosing a DJ or band for your wedding is a personal decision for a couple, there's no denying that live musicians can be an absolutely classic addition to your celebration. Make sure to do research to have your band fit the style and song selection you want for the evening.  Photo By Tailor James; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Leave With a Sparkler Exit  At the end of the evening (or before you head to the after party), have your guests line up for a sparkler send-off. It's a beautiful end to celebrations around those you love.

A TikToker called Madison Mulkey went viral after she said she served Chili's at her wedding.  The comments were mostly positive, although some questioned whether staff were properly compensated.  In a follow-up video, Mulkey said she tipped the staff ‚Äî though some users still raise doubts.  Top editors give you the stories you want ‚Äî delivered right to your inbox each weekday. Loading Something is loading. Thanks for signing up! Access your favorite topics in a personalized feed while you're on the go. download the app Email address By clicking ‚ÄòSign up‚Äô, you agree to receive marketing emails from Insider as well as other partner offers and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy  A bride went viral with a TikTok video about serving Chili's at her wedding, framing it as a unique and cost-efficient option. The response was generally positive, with many applauding the idea and saying they wished they had thought of it themselves.  She also received curious questions and some criticism about whether it imposed extra work on her wedding staff, which prompted her to make a follow-up video saying that she tipped all service workers involved. Despite her attempted clarification, some viewers were unconvinced and alleged that she deleted a previous comment saying she hadn't tipped them.  Still, the apparent hack has inspired others to think more creatively about wedding food ‚Äî so as long as restaurant and ceremony workers are properly compensated.  Mulkey did not immediately respond to multiple requests from Insider for comment.  Madison Mulkey, a photographer with over 28,000 TikTok followers, posted a video on Sunday explaining why she chose the restaurant chain Chili's for her wedding food.  She said the main attraction was the low cost ‚Äî $1,950 for 99 guests. The food included chicken tenders, sliders, cajun chicken pasta, and salad. According to The Knot, the average price for traditional wedding catering can cost $75 a guest, which for Mulkey, amounted to nearly $7,500 total.  She said there were some unexpected complications that arose because they didn't want to pay the delivery fee ‚Äî which would have been $300, she said in a comment. They threw their wedding on St. Patrick's Day weekend, and the restaurant was packed, so they had to pick up the food early at 11 a.m. and keep it cool before the service which was at 6 p.m.  Normally, Chili's workers would deliver and set it up, Mulkey said. But since they picked the food up directly from the restaurant, her hired servers ‚Äî who were mostly hired for cleaning, she said ‚Äî were forced to do a lot of the food preparations. She added that her coordinator helped them.  "Everyone made it work, thank goodness," Mulkey said in the clip, which has been viewed over 1.3 million times. "Our situation was rare. I'm sure if you order from Chili's in any other regard they would serve it and it would all be so hassle-free."  The reaction was mostly positive, with people saying they would be excited to find out a wedding they attended was serving Chili's, and that society should normalize scaled-down weddings like this.  "I would be so hype to find out the wedding food was chili's," a top comment with over 7,000 likes said. "This is my dream," someone else wrote.  The official Chili's Grill & Bar TikTok account even left a comment calling the video "iconic."  However, some people worried that Mulkey's wedding staffers were forced to take on more work.  "I'm all for this, but as someone who works in the industry, this sounds like a nightmare for your staff and coordinator," one top comment with over 1,600 likes said. "You should have paid for delivery."  A comment with over 2,200 likes said they'd give the poster an "A for creativity" but critiqued that the food was 7 hours old, which probably stressed the staff out.  The concerns for her staff prompted Mulkey to make a follow-up video. She assured viewers that she tipped the Chili's kitchen staff $300, and tipped the coordinator and the servers on top of their hourly payment.  "All they did was make the food, help the buffet run efficiently, and then clean up," Mulkey said of the servers. "I didn't ask anyone to work outside of their bounds or their means."  Viewers, however, did not seem entirely convinced. Several comments on the follow-up video accused her of deleting a comment from her original viral video where they said she told another user she hadn't tipped anyone extra since it was included in their original payment (Insider was unable to find and verify the original comment).  Someone also claimed that Chili's managers aren't able to receive tips which prompted them to ask how she was able to tip them. (Insider could not independently verify this but has reached out to the company for comment.)  "Maybe they didn't take it, I have no idea what they did with it," Mulkey wrote in response. "We gave chilis a lump sum."

If you're running out of unique venues or destinations to have your wedding, look no further. Weddings in space are now a thing and we heard it is truly out of this world.  If the thought of nuptials on Earth sound common and boring, a space travel company wants to give you the chance to get hitched at a venue looking down on the third rock from the sun instead.  The company, called Space Perspective, is offering couples a memorable way to say ‚ÄúI do‚Äù ‚Äî putting the bride and groom into orbit using a carbon-neutral balloon with giant windows to make the most of the ultimate view of planet Earth.  According to Jane Poynter, the co-founder of Space Perspective, the waiting list to get married amongst the stars is already light-years long.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve already had people wanting to be the first marriage in space, so we‚Äôll see who is the first,‚Äù Poynter told The Cool Down.  ‚ÄúUnlike all other spacecraft whereby the crewed compartment separates from one flight system mid-flight and transfers to another flight system, Spaceship Neptune‚Äôs capsule remains secured to the SpaceBalloon the entire flight from liftoff to splashdown, creating a seamlessly safe and gentle flight,‚Äù she explained.  The website said the technology the spacecraft uses has already been ‚Äúproven,‚Äù as it has been used for decades by NASA teams and other government agencies to ‚Äúlift research telescopes and other heavy, sensitive instruments.‚Äù  Space Perspective was founded by two former crew members of Biosphere 2, an Earth system science research facility located in Arizona, which was originally constructed to explore the potential of closed ecological systems in supporting human life during outer-space missions.  Vincent Bachet, Space Perspective lead and development engineer, added that Neptune‚Äôs windows are going to be ‚Äúthe biggest windows flown into space.‚Äù  Using hyper-resistant materials and a special anti-UV coating, Space Perspective co-founder and co-CEO Taber MacCallum called them ‚Äúthe quintessential part of the experience.‚Äù  Couples who are interesting in the unique wedding experience can join the waitlist on Space Perspective‚Äôs website for late 2024.  Source: NY Post
Why, you might ask? Well, according to Olivia, it had everything to do with the speech she made at the ceremony.

If you asked Carolina Favero Braga if she would end up with Freud Milice as she began her emergency room rotation in 2015, her answer would likely be a resounding no. The twosome worked alongside each other for two weeks at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn when she was a medical school student and he was a resident. As Carolina puts it, their courtship wasn‚Äôt exactly love at first sight. ‚ÄúI was skeptical of his big personality and braggadocios behavior,‚Äù Carolina admits. ‚ÄúOn our first few days working together, he told me he loved house parties, red wine, and older women. Eye roll.‚Äù  But, in a plot twist of romantic comedy proportions, Freud managed to get Carolina‚Äôs number and would text her after every shift‚Äîand even when she traveled to Florida. ‚ÄúOn the day I was returning to New York, he knew I was anxious about flying, and sent me Angus and Julia Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄòBig Jet Plane‚Äô single to keep me calm throughout the flight. When I landed at JFK, he surprised me and was waiting at baggage claim. Five days later, we went on our first official date. As they say, the rest is history.‚Äù  Fast-forward to June 5, 2020, when the couple was taking a socially distanced trip to the Catskills. As physicians, both Carolina and Freud were on the frontlines of the Covid-19 pandemic and took a well-deserved vacation once restrictions began to loosen. ‚ÄúWhen we arrived, the hotel staff recommended a walk in the garden prior to dinner,‚Äù she shares. ‚ÄúWe got ready and while walking the garden, Freud got down on one knee. I am sure he had more to say but all I remember is, ‚ÄòWill you marry me?‚Äô‚Äù The answer? A resounding yes.  When it came to planning their September 3, 2022, wedding, the couple wanted their special day to highlight the bride‚Äôs Brazilian background and the groom‚Äôs Haitian roots. They enlisted wedding planner Nathalie Cadet-James of Luxe Fete, who had the perfect spot in mind: Itapororoca Villa in Trancoso, Brazil. ‚ÄúThere is the essence of West Africa in this rustic Brazilian beach town,‚Äù the bride explains. ‚ÄúWith its scenic backdrops and rich culture, we knew this was the perfect place to share our love story with family and friends.‚Äù  With 80 of their closest friends and family members in attendance, their destination was a beautiful representation of Carolina and Freud in every way imaginable. ‚ÄúAs an interracial couple, it was important for us to highlight our different backgrounds,‚Äù the bride shares. ‚ÄúNathalie is Haitian-American, and she really understood who we were as individuals, but also as a couple. Her excitement to celebrate our love story was noticeable from before we even officially hired her.‚Äù Read on for an intimate look at Carolina and Freud‚Äôs wedding festivities, as photographed by Heather Waraksa.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Carolina and Freud didn‚Äôt have to look too far for wedding inspiration. Elements of Trancoso‚Äôs seaside beauty were woven throughout the weekend. From watercolor illustrations to magenta accents that pay tribute to the local bougainvillea flowers, the invitation suite from LetterHeads Miami gave guests the perfect glimpse of what was to come.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  The couple kicked off the festivities with a beach party the night before the wedding. Carolina stunned in a white dress from Farm Rio, while Freud looked effortlessly elegant in a white button-down from Peter Millar and matching shorts.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúOur wedding [weekend] didn‚Äôt have a traditional timeline,‚Äù the bride shares. ‚ÄúWe had our maid of honor and best man make their speeches during the welcome party so they could enjoy themselves. We know the effort it took for our guests to celebrate with us and we wanted them to enjoy themselves to the fullest.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  I don‚Äôt know how to describe it, but I knew the dress was made for me.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Come the wedding day, the bride wore a strapless gown from Valentini Spose, which beautifully fulfilled her ‚Äúclean and timeless vision.‚Äù She shares, ‚ÄúI truly believed that this was my day and wanted to wear something that made me feel spectacular. I was also three months postpartum when I started shopping for a wedding dress, so it was important for me to feel confident in it." Carolina adds, "I don‚Äôt know how to describe it, but I knew the dress was made for me.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  When it came to accessorizing her gown, Carolina knew she wanted to support women-owned businesses. She opted for a veil by Jennifer Leigh Couture Veils, Julia Vaughn jewelry, and a special pair of shoes from Brother Vellies. ‚ÄúDuring the beginning of the pandemic, I followed [Brother Vellies founder] Aurora James on Instagram,‚Äù Carolina explains. ‚ÄúIt had to be fate that [she] designed a bridal shoe line for HBO‚Äôs Insecure. I texted Nathalie and the team and said, ‚ÄòI know I don‚Äôt have a dress yet, but I know this is the shoe.‚Äô So, I actually bought my bridal shoes before I had a dress!‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Meanwhile, the groom suited up in a custom navy tuxedo from Suitsupply. Rounding out the look was a tie from Tom Ford, Herm√®s shoes, and his everyday accessories. ‚ÄúFreud wore his watch and a bracelet which was engraved with his daughter‚Äôs name,‚Äù Carolina adds.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Prior to the ceremony, the couple had an ‚Äúintimate and emotional‚Äù first look. ‚ÄúWe wanted to have a moment between us before sharing ‚Äòus‚Äô with everyone else,‚Äù the groom explains.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Upon arrival, guests could grab some water, local juices, or a monogrammed coconut as they listened to a soothing setlist from the string quartet group Quarteto De Cordas de Trancoso.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúOur ceremony was on the beach underneath coconut trees with a wooden altar decorated with bougainvillea,‚Äù the bride shares. ‚ÄúIt was very simple, but elegant at the same time.‚Äù The view of the ocean was a welcomed bonus.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Carolina glided down the aisle to Felix Mendelssohn‚Äôs ‚ÄúMarcha Nupcial,‚Äù with her father and a bouquet of local flowers in tow.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Freud spent months writing his vows during his night shifts, promising to ‚Äúbe present, to be here next week, next month, next year, and the year after that.‚Äù Meanwhile, Carolina performed a song she often sings to their daughter at night. Her favorite lyrics: ‚ÄúI love you in the morning, and in the afternoon. I love you in the evening, and underneath the moon.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  The newlyweds slipped on their wedding bands from Boccardo Jewelers, shared a kiss, and recessed down the aisle to Bob Marley‚Äôs ‚ÄúIs This Love.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Make time to enjoy special moments with each other. It goes by so fast!  Photo by Heather Waraksa  After the ceremony, Carolina and Freud snuck away to take some pictures with photographer Heather Waraksa. ‚Äú‚Äã‚ÄãMake time to enjoy special moments with each other,‚Äù the couple recommends. ‚ÄúIt goes by so fast!‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúOur reception decor is what [our florist] Katia Criscuolo calls 'brasilidade sofisticada'‚Äîor 'sophisticated Brazilianness,'‚Äù Carolina shares. ‚ÄúShe incorporated local materials and tones in the lighting, linens, and place setting. There was one long table in the reception area with no assigned seating, which was to be decorated with magenta flowers among greenery.‚Äù The bride‚Äôs favorite area was the dessert room‚Äîa bougainvillea-adorned space that displayed ‚Äúhundreds of sweets‚Äù on floating trays.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  If guests were craving fresh air, they could hang out in one of the venue‚Äôs chill outdoor seating areas.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  True to their love story, Carolina and Freud shared a sweet first dance to Angus and Julia Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Jet Plane.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  While the newlyweds opted for a buffet style of local Bahian-inspired food‚Äîcourtesy of O Cacau‚Äîthey tapped Confet Doceria to whip up a four-tiered cake. ‚ÄúWe had two different flavors. One layer was white cake with brigadeiro filling, [which is a traditional Brazilian dessert],‚Äù the bride explains. ‚ÄúThe other layers were white cake with dulce de leche filling.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Since Carolina and Freud love music‚Äîthey have a shared fondness of hip-hop‚Äîthey wanted to find a DJ who understood their taste. ‚ÄúWe worked closely with our DJ, Nath Carreiro, to play music that played significant parts in our lives both as individuals and as a couple,‚Äù the groom notes. "We shared with her Spotify playlists for both the welcome party and the wedding. DJ Nath was a smashing success!" In fact, the newlyweds even infiltrated the DJ booth during the evening with their daughter, Celine.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúWe were on the dance floor for most of the wedding,‚Äù Freud explains. But, according to the couple, guests left the event with more than some new dance moves. ‚ÄúBecause many of our friends had never been to Brazil before, we focused a high level of detail on the experience that our guests would have,‚Äù Carolina shares. ‚ÄúFreud created a WhatsApp group with all the guests as a way for everyone to connect a few weeks prior to the wedding. Our guests were able to get to know each other and it made it even more special on the wedding day. The group is still going strong to this day!‚Äù Whether it‚Äôs an inner circle or excellent vendors, no love story is complete without the people cheering you on along the way.
