A couple set to get married in June says their wedding guests were kicked out of an upstate New York hotel to make room for migrants .  Gary Moretti and Deanna Mifsud booked their dream wedding in Lippincott Manor and had reserved a block of 30 rooms for guests to stay at The Crossroads Hotel nearby in Newburgh, New York. They reportedly expected 160 guests from across the country to attend their June 24 wedding.  The couple says their plans were turned upside down when they learned their hotel block had been cancelled to make room for migrants that were being sent upstate by New York City Mayor Eric Adams. The Crossroads Hotel was tapped to accept migrants who were being bused from New York City to hotels in Westchester and the Hudson Valley.  "We woke up the other morning and got a phone call from my sister...to check out the news," Moretti told " Jesse Watters Primetime " on Tuesday. "No phone call, no text message, no email from them about any cancellations. I call them up and ... I asked them about the migrants going in there, is it going to be safe for my guests and ourselves to be there. They said, ‚ÄòNo, you have nothing to worry about‚Äô and in my heart I'm thinking, ‚ÄòOK, cool.‚Äô They‚Äôre like... ‚ÄòYour contract has been cancelled.'"  REDDIT USER SLAMMED FOR PLANNING TO ATTEND A TAYLOR SWIFT CONCERT INSTEAD OF HER OWN MOTHER'S WEDDING  The couple said hotel officials told them there was nothing they could do, and it was a "complete madhouse" in there. The soon-to-be newlyweds were instructed to contact Choice Management, which oversees the hotel. They said they played a "back and forth game" talking to The Crossroads Hotel and Choice, to no avail. Now they are scrambling to find accommodations for their quickly approaching wedding .  CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP  Mifsud said the couple‚Äôs venue, which has no connection to the hotel, has been "awesome" and is trying to help them draft ideas where to stay, but it has been met with challenges.  "It's also the air show weekend," she told "Jesse Watters Primetime." "So, everything is completely sold out. The hotels that are even talking to us with possible rooms, they want to charge us anywhere from like $300 to $400 a night. Now, our transportation, everybody (is) going to be scattered. So, we have one hotel that has been doing great. We have about 15 rooms blocked with them, but...we don't have a place to go. We're looking at Airbnbs."

Derek Hough and Hayley Erbert are headed towards the altar, while balancing expectations of their wedding day.  In a new interview in Brides magazine, the Dancing with the Stars alum, who turns 38 on Wednesday, and his fianc√©e, 28, revealed that the price of planning a wedding has come as a bit of a shock.  "It's a very eye-opening experience, and when you start to add everything up, it's pretty wild," Hough said.  As the pieces for their ceremony and reception come together, the couple revealed that they have already chosen a venue, and that fireworks and a first dance ‚Äî naturally ‚Äî are in the cards.  For the choreographer and actor, and his dancer bride-to-be, the wedding isn't so much about "perfection" as it is about a "vibe," which is important when it comes to the guest list.  "A rule that we've set is that we don't want to catch up with people on the day of the wedding," Erbert said. "We're inviting people that maybe we haven't seen in a while, but every time we get together with them, it's like we pick up right where we left off, or they're people that have been consistently in our lives throughout the years. We're not going to catch up with people, we're just gonna have a blast with people."  Amy and Stuart Photography for Brides  Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.  The couple, who got engaged last June after a seven-year courtship, intend to have a wedding celebration that perfectly reflects who they are.  "We're fun!" Hough said. "What we gravitate towards isn't always the most lavish option. We're playing with different approaches to certain things so that the day still feels elegant and beautiful and magical, but grounded and down to earth and just approachable."  He added, "We want the entire day to be a blast."  And as for that first dance, Erbert revealed that it will be a special moment, even if Hough wasn't so interested in the wedding tradition at first.  "We perform for a living, so we just want this dance to be for us," she said. "We don't want to perform for anyone else."  Adds Hough: "We want to feel good and comfortable, but we don't need to be perfect‚Ä¶ That's a lot less important to me than just looking into her eyes as we're rocking back and forth. I want to feel truly present in that moment."  As the big day draws near, Hough said that the couple has remained grounded and focused on what's really important.  "At the end of the day we come back to, 'Why are we doing this? What is the reason for this?'" Hough said. "And the reason is for the two of us. That's really it."

A newlywed widower whose bride died in a golf-cart crash after the couple's wedding reception last month has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the alleged drunken driver charged in her death.  The suit, filed Wednesday in South Carolina's Ninth Judicial Circuit Court of Common Pleas by Aric Hutchinson and two other people hurt in the crash, names more than a half dozen defendants including Jamie Lee Komoroski, who police arrested in connection to the April 28th death of Samantha Miller 34.  Miller, from Charlotte, North Carolina, was killed in the Folly Beach crash in Charleston County.  Three other of Miller's family members, including Hutchinson, suffered major injuries in the two-vehicle late evening crash.  The lawsuit also names five local businesses as defendants and claims Komoroski, 25, had been "bar hopping" the day of the wreck, which according to an arrest affidavit, involved a rented Toyota Camry slamming into the golf cart.  In addition to wrongful death, the 28-page suit also accuses the defendants of gross negligence, reckless hiring, supervision and training as well as "negligent infliction of emotional distress."  'Noticeably and visibly intoxicated'  A responding Folly Beach police officer, who found the victims on the ground at the scene, said the driver of the Camry smelled strongly of alcohol and admitted to drinking "one beer and a drink with tequila about an hour ago."  ‚ÄúDespite being noticeably and visibly intoxicated at each of these establishments,‚Äù the lawsuit reads, ‚ÄúJaime Komoroski continued to be served, provided, and/or allowed to consume alcohol in each of them.‚Äù  Former Raider enters plea in DUI caseEx-Raider Henry Ruggs pleads guilty to driving drunk at 156 mph, causing fatal crash  "This case is about keeping our community safe from drunk drivers, and an important part of that effort is making sure the establishments we entrust with liquor licenses live up to their responsibility to serve alcohol responsibly," the family's Charleston-based attorney Danny Dalton said.  The plaintiffs ask for a jury trial and seek punitive damages among other costs in connection to the case.  Just married  Earlier this month, Folly Beach Public Safety Department Chief Andrew Gilreath told USA TODAY Hutchinson and Miller were married just hours before the 10:15 p.m. wreck.  Police said data retrieved from Komoroski‚Äôs rental car show she was driving 65 mph and briefly hit the brakes before she slammed into the golf cart.  Komoroski, who is from Charleston, refused a sobriety and a breath test, according to her arrest affidavit. She was arrested and medical personnel drew a blood sample from her.  Prince Harry in harrowing "car chase"Prince Harry, Duchess Meghan say they were in 'near catastrophic' car chase with paparazzi  According to additional court papers, when her blood was drawn her Blood Alcohol Content was 0.261, more than three times the legal limit to drive.  She faces charges including reckless vehicular homicide and driving under the influence causing great bodily injury and is due in court next month for a hearing, court records show.  Komoroski's attorney could not immediately be reached by USA TODAY.  Natalie Neysa Alund covers breaking and trending news for USA TODAY. Reach her at nalund@usatoday.com and follow her on Twitter @nataliealund.

Getting engaged, planning a wedding, and preparing for life with your favorite person is one of the most exciting and joyful times of your life, but it can also be rife with familial conflicts, disagreements over the budget, and the need for a lot of compromises. Still, every challenge you face while planning your wedding is an opportunity to improve your relationship, strengthen your bond, and deepen your communication skills as a couple.  ‚ÄúDefining your shared values, navigating conflict, getting on the same page in terms of finances, deciding how we spend time in relationships outside of our primary relationships‚Äîany number of topics that come up during wedding planning need to get negotiated on an ongoing basis,‚Äù says Jennifer Uhrlass, licensed marriage and family therapist at Modern MFT in New York City. ‚ÄúIt has to be an ongoing, open dialogue, which is really training for the ongoing negotiations that are going that are going to take place along the course of the relationship.‚Äù  Meet the Expert Jennifer Uhrlass is a licensed marriage and family therapist (LMFT) at Modern MFT in New York City.  Ahead, Uhrlass speaks to us about how this crucial window of time‚Äîthe engagement period‚Äîcan be an opportunity for couples to strengthen their relationship and build new skills as partners.  Communicate and Compromise  Every aspect of your wedding is about the two of you as a couple, which means you‚Äôll both need to compromise to create a day that speaks to two different personalities. Sometimes it‚Äôs easy: Maybe one partner doesn‚Äôt care about the signature cocktails or the other partner doesn‚Äôt have a preference for the reception exit. But when only one partner is set on a destination wedding, or wants a religious ceremony, or won‚Äôt trim the guest list, the middle ground can be much harder to find.  The key, says Uhrlass, is making sure you take the time to fully listen to and process your partner‚Äôs wishes‚Äîand express your own‚Äîso that you can come to an agreement you are both on board with. ‚ÄúDo you truly, truly hear and understand the other person‚Äôs perspective, or are you just glossing over stuff and moving forward without understanding?‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere are times when you can miss each other‚Äôs message‚Äîthe message sent is not always the message received. Recognize the importance of slowing down the interaction, making sure you heard and understood what your partner said, and making sure that you can come to a mutual understanding.‚Äù  Get Into an Argument‚Äîor Several  Arguments about the details of your wedding‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs your partner‚Äôs desire to torpedo the guest list by adding three tables of fraternity brothers or your own insistence on a specific type of music‚Äîare precursors to future conflicts in your life together. How you approach and solve these conflicts helps you lay the foundation for healthy and productive disagreements in the future. ‚ÄúLearning how to navigate conflict effectively with your partner is essential,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúYou have to be able to do that well with each other because the problems are going to be perpetual. There's always going to be a need to navigate and negotiate ongoing issues throughout the course of the relationship.‚Äù Today it‚Äôs the guest list and cake flavors; tomorrow it may be where to send your kids to school or how to spend your year-end bonus. ‚ÄúOften, partners tend to get caught up in the content of a disagreement, when it can be much more productive to focus on their process of engagement when it comes to a particular conflict,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs important is to learn how to navigate that conflict effectively; not so much trying to avoid conflict altogether, but to recognize that conflict is a healthy part of a relationship.‚Äù  Photo by Getty Images; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Set Family Boundaries  Weddings can bring out the best in your family, but there's no denying that they can also bring out the worst. Explaining to your parents that you won‚Äôt be tying the knot at your childhood church, telling your mother-in-law her entire bridge club didn‚Äôt make the guest list, breaking the news to your siblings that their toddlers won‚Äôt be invited to the reception: These family conflicts (and many others) have the potential to put you and your partner on opposite teams. As you prepare for your wedding, it's important to remember that you‚Äôre also developing a new team of your own. ‚ÄúOne of the natural challenges around the topic of getting married is that there‚Äôs a shift: You were part of one family unit and now you‚Äôre cultivating a new family unit in your relationship with your partner,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúMoving through this identity shift can bring up a lot of conflicts and a lot of emotion.‚Äù  Use this time to set collective boundaries as a couple, understand each other‚Äôs family history, and prioritize your partnership. ‚ÄúIt is possible to work through this through dialogue and understanding each person‚Äôs perspective,‚Äù says Urhlass. ‚Äú‚ÄôYour mom wants this, however, for us, we‚Äôre also weighing this and this,‚Äô‚Äîyou want to make sure that you get on the same page so you can make decisions together as a unit.‚Äù  Talk About Money  How you choose to finance your wedding is a microcosm of the larger financial decisions you‚Äôll make in the future: How you put together a budget, and whether you‚Äôll stick to it; whether you‚Äôre willing to take on credit card debt or loans, or accept money from either set of parents; whether your individual incomes and spending patterns are causing unseen conflict. Deciding whether you want to splurge on a band or spend less on a DJ is a precursor to future conversations about which house is in your budget, whether you‚Äôll put a vacation on your credit card, and how often you need to upgrade your television. ‚ÄúNavigating issues related to finances is a common point of contention,‚Äù says Urhlass. ‚ÄúIt could bring up difficult emotions such as fear or feelings of inadequacy. There may also be significant power differentials; in a relationship where there's a disparity in income, it can negatively impact a couple's ability to address issues in a productive way. If partners haven't reached a place where they feel comfortable, there can be a lot to unpack there. If you're just leaving it festering in the background, and you're not really addressing it, then they will tend to get worse, or stay unaddressed, which can lead to contempt later on.‚Äù  Give Each Other Space to Destress  Every major life change brings a heightened period of stress, and you and your partner will need to know how to take care of yourselves‚Äîand each other‚Äîto get through them. ‚ÄúLearning to take care of yourself through the very difficult wedding planning process is, I think, an essential element to navigating life effectively,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúIf we're stressed to the max and we're not taking care of ourselves, we're not working out, we're not getting our proper sleep, we're not getting nutrition, or we're not spending time with friends, it‚Äôs going to have a major impact on how we approach topics and conflict and disagreements. It's really important to step back and stick to routines that are helpful to manage the stress effectively.‚Äù  This could mean planning your meal tasting around your partner‚Äôs weekly round of golf, making sure you have enough money set aside for weekend excursions (instead of putting all travel on hold until your honeymoon), or maintaining your Friday date night‚Äîno wedding talk allowed. ‚ÄúSet aside time to have space with each other,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúSpend time with each other nurturing your relationship, as opposed to talking about the to-do list for the wedding.  Define Your Shared Values  A shared vision for your big day can also help you define the elements that will become your family‚Äôs values moving forward: How closely will you follow religious traditions? How often will you see your parents and siblings? What constitutes a worthwhile financial investment? How do you, as a couple and as individuals, define and deepen your relationships with your friends? ‚ÄúTwo people can have very different beliefs and philosophies about money, or [anything] across the board,‚Äù says Urhlass. ‚ÄúThat doesn't necessarily mean that they're incompatible. It just might mean that there's more to talk about, that they understand each other and make sure that they can be on the same page in terms of their long-term goals, their values, and how they want to move forward in their lives developing a sense of identity as a couple.‚Äù

May 17, 2023 12:55 am | Updated 12:55 am IST - HYDERABAD  A 40-year-old man allegedly beat his wife to death and later took his own life, at Yellareddyguda in SR Nagar police limits in the wee hours of Tuesday.  Police said the woman, Premalatha, 35, was found bludgeoned to death with a rod. Reportedly, the incident took place after midnight, when the couple returned from the woman‚Äôs house in Thumkunta after their wedding anniversary celebrations. Their two children, who are in high school, were at the grandmother‚Äôs house in Thumkunta for the ongoing summer vacation.  It is suspected that Janardhan and Premalatha were engaged in a heated argument, which turned violent.  According to the police, Janardhan, an alcoholic, had left the family last year. After his wife, an employee at a dental clinic, filed a complaint, police traced him later in April.  Police shifted the bodies for post-mortem. An investigation is under way.  (Roshni, suicide prevention helpline: 81420-20033/ 81420-20044, from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily)

He got up, held the hand of the host and said, ‚ÄúWe can walk around this thing like we are getting married or something.‚Äù But the host intervened, saying, ‚ÄúGuys, I am already married.‚Äù To this, Ranbir replied, ‚ÄúYeah, me too" and both of them took their seats again. A Reddit user commented, ‚ÄúIt's cute how Ranbir always happens to know everything that's been trending on social media even though he isn't there officially, fake account.‚Äù Another assumed that the actor can even be on Reddit under a different name. ‚ÄúThere's no way that Ranbir isn't a member of this sub. Hi Ranbir. I liked you in TJMM,‚Äù the comment read.  SHARE THIS ARTICLE ON

Weddings are supposed to be joyful, but this joy can be accompanied by a lot of stress. Alongside choosing the menu, flowers and decorations and sorting the table plan, body image ‚Äì how we think and feel about the way we look ‚Äì can cause worries, too.  We could not identify any previous research that had formally looked at how brides in the UK felt about their body image. To address this, and fill the gap in our knowledge, our research explored how brides felt about their body image in the run-up to their wedding. We focused in particular on any appearance concerns that they had and how these made them feel ‚Äì from the planning stage right up to the big day itself.  One hundred and thirty-four women took part in either an interview or an online survey. They were a mix of women planning their weddings and those who had been married in the past three years. Many women experienced feelings of pressure and expectation to look a certain way on their wedding day.  This article is part of Quarter Life, a series about issues affecting those of us in our twenties and thirties. From the challenges of beginning a career and taking care of our mental health, to the excitement of starting a family, adopting a pet or just making friends as an adult. The articles in this series explore the questions and bring answers as we navigate this turbulent period of life.  You may be interested in:  Love Island ditches fast fashion: how reality celebrities influence young shoppers‚Äô habits  How to make your clothes last longer ‚Äì it‚Äôs good for your bank account and the environment too  It‚Äôs not just weddings ‚Äì how celebrating small wins and unconventional milestones can bring joy  They felt that this pressure came from various sources, including family and friends. They told us that others‚Äô perceptions of how they looked affected their own feelings, both on the wedding day and afterwards. One said:  If you know other people think you look nice then you have more confidence.  Another told us:  I didn‚Äôt want to feel ashamed of my appearance. I knew there would be a lot of attention and comments on it. Didn‚Äôt want to feel like I‚Äôd let people down‚Ä¶there were lots of questions about my appearance and dresses mainly from other women. It felt like how I looked was part of the ‚Äòdecoration‚Äô in the same way the table settings and order of service was.  Many of the women we spoke to felt the need to adhere to these pressures through fear of judgment and the expectation that all brides should look beautiful.  Looking back  The knowledge that wedding photographs and videos would provide permanent visual evidence of how they looked added to body image pressures. One said:  I wanted to look back at the photographs and feel 100% comfortable with what I saw.  The pressure felt by the women we spoke to also stemmed from the bridal industry, which perpetuates norms and assumptions about how brides should look. One woman, for example, talked about a bad experience she had in a bridalwear shop:  I felt the ladies in the dress shop were quite judgemental, saying I needed to eat better and basically lose weight, so I felt very negative towards me.  Nearly 70% of the women we spoke to who were planning their weddings intended to lose weight in preparation for their wedding day. The pressure to lose weight had a significant effect on their feelings and emotions. One said:  I‚Äôm really worried that preparing my weight for my wedding will re-trigger my anorexia and I don‚Äôt think people talk about the unnecessary pressure for brides and grooms to lose weight.  Some of the women reported going to extreme measures to achieve their weight-loss goals, including surgery. One had a gastric band fitted in the run-up to the wedding: this is a band around the stomach that limits its expansion, leading to feeling full sooner. Another had a tummy tuck ‚Äì cosmetic surgery to improve the shape of the stomach area.  Among the women we spoke to who were already married, only 27% had reached the weight they wanted to for their wedding. One said:  I was distressed when I realised I wouldn‚Äôt achieve this weight. I then felt fine approaching the day itself. However, I felt embarrassed after seeing photos of me and regretted getting married at my weight.  Our findings back up what other researchers have found in countries outside of the UK, such as in Australia and the US. This research has drawn attention to the powerful pressures related to wedding appearance and the expectation of how women should look when getting married.  If you are getting married, then it is completely natural for you to want to look your best, but prioritise your own wellbeing, too.  If one of your friends or family members is getting married, or if you work in the wedding industry, be conscious of what you are saying to the brides in your life. Make sure you are not inadvertently adding any pressures or expectations to them by commenting on their appearance during what can already be a stressful time. Focus on the joy and connection that is the real heart of a wedding.

Popular actress, Dalljiet Kaur tied the marital knot with UK-based businessman, Nikhil Patel, in a dreamy wedding ceremony on March 18, 2023. The actress had a second wedding, after her divorce from actor, Shalin Bhanot, and shifted to Nairobi, Kenya with her new family. Dalljiet has been settling into a new environment with her hubby, Nikhil Patel and their kids, Aariyana and Jaydon.  advertisement  Dalljiet Kaur reveals she and her hubby, Nikhil will go on a strict 8-month strict  In one of her vlogs, Dalljiet Kaur opened up about her married life and revealed how she is adjusting to a new place. Talking about the same, she shared that she and Nikhil ate everything unhealthy for the first month of their wedding, but now they will follow a strict 8-month diet regime. Revealing that they will eat the same food for 8 months, the actress said:  advertisement  "It has been a month since our marriage, and we had planned to eat everything unhealthy for the first month and enjoy the new place. After that, we are going for an 8-month strict diet regime with a healthy prepped meals diet with our trainer. We would be eating the same food for 8 months. This will be our last week of eating unhealthy food. There will be a complete plan counting our macros, calories, and proteins every day."  Recommended Read: Inside Glimpses From Ishita Dutta's 'Godh Bharai', Sister, Tanushree Dutta Looks Unrecognisable  advertisement  advertisement.  Dalljiet Kaur on looking chubby at her wedding  Dalljiet Kaur made for a beautiful bride on her initiate wedding with Nikhil Patel, looking gorgeous in a white lehenga. However, in the same vlog, the actress mentioned how she looked chubby in her wedding photos and blamed Nikhil for the same. Revealing the reason, Dalljiet said:  advertisement  "When we were getting married, like every other bride, I even wanted to look the prettiest and ripped. But my husband told me, 'Eat and enjoy'. My trainer would hate me for this, I did take the membership and didn't turn up at the gym at all. In the two months, I barely went twice and wasted the money. He kept saying, 'Shaadi hai, enjoy karo', so to the people who told me that I looked chubby at the wedding, it was all because of him. Now, we have our last week, post that I will be seriously following the regime."  advertisement  Dalljiet Kaur is figuring out the transition to a new place  Dalljiet also opened up about shifting to a new country and talked about the transition in her life. These days, the actress is busy revamping her new house and painting the living room's wall to kill time and improve the aesthetics. Despite ominous black clouds and a thunderstorm warning issued by Environment Canada, Dominic and Alanis said their vows under the watchful gaze of the Dolphins, friends and family.  Friends of the bride and groom reached out to Castanet to let us know about the big day. Marnie says she is a friend of the groom, "they were actually supposed to be married during COVID, and instead had a very premature baby that took up their time."  Needless to say the wedding was postponed, but after the arrival of their second child in January, the couple decided to tie the knot this May.  "So they decided that while they have family in town, they're going to just get married today. An inexpensive way to do it absolutely. Everybody's perfectly happy and we're super excited that they're just gonna get it done," Marnie says.  The young couple's nuptials got sidetracked by COVID-19 and two babies later they decided to make it legal.  "I know they'd be amazed if they saw their picture on Castanet," said Robert Adams.

Cassie Parrott trims the stem of a flower as she creates an arrangement for a client last Wednesday at her home floral design studio in southwest Cedar Rapids. Parrott opened Parrott Floral Co. last year. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  CEDAR RAPIDS -- Cassie Parrott has expressed herself through flowers all of her adult life.  ‚ÄúFor me, it‚Äôs the creative side, and getting to share my artistic abilities through florals,‚Äù Parrott said one recent morning. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm horrible at drawing or painting or anything like that, but when it comes to being creative on the flower side...‚Äù  Parrott, 32, began working for florists soon after graduating from Cedar Rapids Jefferson High School, just a few blocks from her home. She kept working while completing Kirkwood Community College‚Äôs horticulture program.  Cassie Parrott creates a flower arrangement for a client at her Parrott Floral Co. home design studio last Wednesday in southwest Cedar Rapids. She opened her business last year. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  Advertisement  Gaining some 15 years experience, Parrott and her husband, Joey, decided last year it was time to strike out on her own.  ‚ÄúI had been doing it for other businesses and just decided I wanted to be doing it for myself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI knew what it all entailed, and what I needed.‚Äù  A small toolshed in her backyard became her studio, freshened with new paint and outfitted with work tables and a florist‚Äôs refrigerator to keep blooms fresh.  ‚ÄúThankfully, we had this workshop,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was just storage. We started converting, and it went really quickly after I decided I wanted to for-sure do it.‚Äù  Wedding specialty  Parrott‚Äôs goal is to specialize on weddings, but she‚Äôs taken other business during her start-up.  ‚ÄúFrom the beginning, I knew I was going to have to do some everyday retail,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFriends and family will say, ‚ÄòHey, can you do a birthday bouquet for me tomorrow?‚Äô And I can make it happen.‚Äù  Business News Newsletter Signup Newsletter Signup Delivered to your inbox weekdays Email Please wait... Thank you for joining us! You will begin to receive our Daily Business News updates. Add newsletters@thegazette.com to your contacts.  Without a traditional storefront, which she didn‚Äôt want to invest in, Parrott typically begins the design process in customers‚Äô homes, where being a one-woman operation has its advantages.  ‚ÄúI have the capabilities and the time to actually get to know each one of my brides and give my undivided attention to them and not have to worry about other customers coming in,‚Äù she said.  Large, elaborate displays are popular for this season‚Äôs weddings, she said.  ‚ÄúBig, colorful arches and hanging installations,‚Äù Parrott said. ‚ÄúBig statement pieces are the trendy things right now.‚Äù  Most customers have at least some idea what they‚Äôre after.  ‚ÄúA lot of times they have somewhat of a vision,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve gone to Pinterest or Google or Instagram or TikTok and found pictures they like. I guide them and make it fit within their budget and make their vision come to life for them.‚Äù  Cassie Parrott creates a flower arrangement for a client at her home floral design studio in Cedar Rapids. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  Using social media  Social media also is a key marketing tool.  ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre starting a business, anything free is helpful,‚Äù Parrott said. ‚ÄúAnytime we do a wedding and they post pictures and tag us in it, that helps spread the word.  ‚ÄúThose relationships with other wedding vendors help. A venue, a dress shop, a tux shop, a bakery, we all get together and make a mock wedding, and it‚Äôs photographed and we post that on our socials.‚Äù  Parrott works through a wholesale florist in Illinois and directly with big flower farms in Ecuador and Chile. In-season, she also buys locally grown blooms.  Managing deliveries, she said, is vital.  ‚ÄúWhen somebody‚Äôs buying a bouquet for a birthday or anniversary, they want that to last as long as possible. I want to get that in right before the occasion and get it out to them in the form where it‚Äôs barely started blooming,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWith a wedding, they‚Äôre wanting (the full bloom). Depending what kinds of blooms, I have a process where I get them to their full potential for the wedding day.‚Äù  Friends, family help  Parrott is her namesake company‚Äôs sole full-time employee, but friends and family help with deliveries and building elaborate arrangements. Peak wedding season brings some early-morning starts.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre always one of the first vendors at a wedding on Saturday,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou want to be in and out, so once they start with pictures that‚Äôs all done. By about noon I have everything set up.‚Äù  Cassie Parrott dyes flowers made out of wood shavings to create at floral arrangement for a client Wednesday at her home design studio in southwest Cedar Rapids. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  Despite working through the pandemic‚Äôs lingering supply-chain effects -- Parrott estimates wholesale flower costs have tripled -- she‚Äôs optimistic about her business‚Äô first busy season.  ‚ÄúWhen I opened, my main concern was just getting clients and getting my name out there as my business and myself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve booked 11 weddings since September. For my first eight months, that seems like a pretty good number.‚Äù

Everyone looks forward to Bollywood weddings because they are larger than life and an entire galaxy of stars come together to wish the couple well. However, there were also many B-town celebs who decided to keep their wedding an intimate affair. The trend of having a secret and hush-hush wedding also started after the Covid-19 pandemic.  But, did you know that ‚ÄòVivaah‚Äô actress Amrita Rao married the love of her life RJ Anmol at a temple in Pune on a budget as low as Rs 1,50,000?  View this post on Instagram A post shared by AMRITA RAO üáÆüá≥ (@amrita_rao_insta)  Recently, the couple released a YouTube video on their official channel wherein they elaborated on the cost of their wedding, the venue, and how they were able to pull off a close-knit shaadi in that budget.  In the ‚ÄòAnniversary Special‚Äô episode of ‚ÄòCouple Of Things‚Äô, they took us down memory lane to the place they got married nine years ago.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by RJ Anmol (@rjanmol27)  The handful of people who attended their wedding traveled from Mumbai to Iskcon Temple in Katraj, Pune where the couple secretly tied the knot. As for the stay and other functions like Sangeet, Mehendi, and Karaoke Night, the couple booked a hotel on the outskirts of Pune.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by RJ Anmol (@rjanmol27)  The couple further revealed that the outfits they wore were very traditional and cost not more than Rs 3000 each because they didn‚Äôt want to wear designer clothes. The ‚ÄòMain Hoon Na‚Äô actor also wore all artificial jewellery on her wedding day.  ‚ÄúWhen I told Anmol that I wanted to buy jewellery, he had told me ‚ÄòAbhi q shopping karni hai, tabhi karo na shaadi k baad.‚Äô And when the wedding happened, we were busy building our house so we had no time to shop. So, I wore artificial jewellery top to bottom. I was very angry.‚Äù  In the video, the couple then visited their wedding venue and relived those fond memories.  Amrita further revealed that she also carried her makeup kit and did her wedding makeup herself. Her family members helped her get ready for the special occasion.  They also added that one of the reasons they wanted to get married in Pune was because Amrita‚Äôs grandparents were in Pune so it was easier for them to travel to the venue. Concluding the video, Amrita shared:  ‚ÄúWe always believed that weddings should be about love, not about showing off wealth and ostentation. We wanted our wedding to be a beautiful, intimate affair with just our immediate families & close friends, and we‚Äôre glad we were able to achieve that without spending a fortune.‚Äù  To this, RJ Anmol added, ‚ÄúOur wedding was a reflection of our personalities, and we wanted to keep it humble. We would be happy if this inspires people to opt for budget-friendly weddings too.‚Äù  Clearly, you don‚Äôt have to spend crores to make memories and get married to the love of your life. The stage adaptation of ‚ÄúMonsoon Wedding,‚Äù the 2001 film by Mira Nair made its New York debut earlier this month. Based on a book by Arpita Mukherjee and Sabrina Dhawan, the musical is conceived and directed by Nair, and ‚Äútries to capture the 2001 film‚Äôs spirit,‚Äù according to The New York Times.  The past few months have been magnificent working as music producer to @MiraPagliNair Monsoon Wedding. Our 1st preview marched off Saturday and opening night is this coming Saturday. It‚Äôs truly a beautiful show. The show runs till June 25 and tickets are flying fast. pic.twitter.com/N1HwVgF8mc ‚Äî Sunny Jain (@sunnydrums) May 9, 2023  ‚ÄúMonsoon Wedding‚Äù follows the Vermas, a Punjabi family in Delhi busily preparing for a lavish wedding. As event planners string marigold flower chains and pitch a pole tent for the festivities, mania ensues. The bride-to-be, Aditi, is torn between her feelings for her ex-lover and her soon-to-be husband, the wedding planner falls in love with the family‚Äôs maid, and buried family secrets come to the surface during the days-long celebration. ‚ÄúNair‚Äôs celebration rings joyful and cathartic: as a love song to her home city of Delhi and to her own Punjabi family,‚Äù says the musical‚Äôs synopsis. ‚ÄúAt its core, it‚Äôs a story of families: how they love, rejoice, and endure together.‚Äù  calling all nyers and well wishers to immediately go see Mira Nair‚Äôs brilliant *Monsoon Wedding: The Musical* pic.twitter.com/twgjkJRP5n ‚Äî Manan Ahmed (@sepoy) May 14, 2023  The production was first staged in 2017 at Berkeley Repertory Theater, where it received mixed reviews, the Bay Area Player reported at the time. Work on the adaptation began in 2006, with Nair and the film‚Äôs screenwriter, Dhawan, collaborating with composer Vishal Bhardwaj and the lyricist Susan Birkenhead. Nair told The Times that ‚Äúshe‚Äôd been inspired by the 2004 Broadway revival of ‚ÄúFiddler on the Roof,‚Äù a show built around cultural traditions adapting to survive.  The Times further notes that ‚Äúlike the film, the musical touches upon the fallout of India‚Äôs 1947 partition, brought to life in the characters‚Äô religious, social and economic differences. Nair told the publication that the film is about ‚Äúour families, but so deeply universal ‚Äî this essential story of understanding a whole society and movement through a very personal story.‚Äù  However, the musical deviates a little from the film, in terms of messaging. For the musical, Nair had to revisit one of the film‚Äôs subplots, she told The Times, ‚Äúabout a relative‚Äôs grooming and sexual abuse of two younger family members.‚Äù A ‚Äúconcerted effort‚Äù was made to have ‚Äúthe women question the patriarchy and speak up,‚Äù Nair said. ‚ÄúOther characters who are afflicted by this don‚Äôt shove it under the rug; they make decisions in their own lives that reflect that they will not accept this behavior, which we didn‚Äôt have before.‚Äù  The change is reflective of Nair‚Äôs work which ‚Äúhas never shied away from examining cultural distinctions,‚Äù The Times notes. ‚ÄúMississippi Masala‚Äù (1991) explored the interracial romance between a Black man and Indian American woman, ‚ÄúSalaam Bombay!‚Äù (1988), revolved around children living in the slums.  ‚ÄúMonsoon Wedding‚Äù is currently playing at St. Ann‚Äôs Warehouse in Brooklyn, New York, through June 25.

Shabana Azmi, by her own admission, is playing an ‚Äúultra-glamorous‚Äù role in Karan Johar‚Äôs upcoming film Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani. The actor, in a recent interview, said that she ‚Äúnever felt more beautiful on screen‚Äù and called it a ‚Äúliberating experience‚Äù.  In a chat with ETimes, Shabana recalled an incident from the time she was shooting for the film and had to attend a wedding after pack up. She shared that the attire that she was shooting in was befitting for a wedding so she attended the function in the same clothes and jewellery. ‚ÄúI remember in 2022 while shooting in Delhi for Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani, I had to attend a wedding one evening. After the day‚Äôs shooting, I just took off wearing the saree and jewellery that I was shooting in,‚Äù she said.  Shabana Azmi shared that the film‚Äôs costume designer Manish Malhotra was ‚Äúhorrified‚Äù and said, ‚ÄúHow can you go to a wedding wearing shooting clothes and jewellery? At least let me give you real jewellery.‚Äù But Shabana asked him to ‚Äúrelax‚Äù as it would be completely fine. ‚ÄúAnd it was. I looked quite presentable at the wedding, if I may say so myself,‚Äù she added.  Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani is Karan Johar‚Äôs next directorial. It marks his return as a director after 2016‚Äôs Ae Dil Hai Mushkil (Karan directed shorts in Lust Stories and Ghost Stories, respectively). The film, also starring Alia Bhatt, Ranveer Singh, Dharmendra, Jaya Bachchan, is scheduled to release on July 28.  In an earlier chat with Bollywood Life, Ranveer Singh described Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani as a ‚Äúquintessential Karan Johar movie‚Äù and added, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs vintage Karan Johar, everything that you love about his films ‚Äì the songs, the glamour, the good-looking leads, the family dynamics, the pulpy drama, the humour, the romance, it‚Äôs all packed in there; every trope you‚Äôve seen in Karan Johar movies, his brand of cinema you have loved ‚Äì all there.‚Äù

A SELF-PROCLAIMED curvy girl planning a destination wedding has revealed a swimwear hack that provides a two-in-one vacation outfit.  The genius trick will also save you some space in your suitcase.  1 The trendy hack has been shared in a recent TikTok video Credit: TIKTOK/@trendycurvy  TikToker Kristine (@trendycurvy) shared her swimwear hack in a recent video.  "Its wedding week! Had to show y‚Äôall how to get the most out of your vacation wardrobe," she captioned the clip.  Kristine started her video in a two-piece black swimsuit with a floor-length kimono-style coverup.  "You need a duster like this for every vacation you go on," she said.  "First and foremost, it's a swimwear coverup," she continued.  But that's not its only purpose, Kristine said.  If you want to go to a nice dinner and need an extra outfit, the coverup can turn into a dress.  "Close this up, put a belt around it, some strappy heels, and you're good to go," she said.  "Two outfits in one."  Kristine's video has been viewed more than 105,000 times.  Manny offered congratulatory comments and some even asked where her swimsuit and coverup were from.  Meanwhile, another TikToker has shared the perfect bikini for a summer day at the beach.  Samantha Riehl showed the garment from the brand Sommer Swim to her more than 670,000 followers.  The bright red bikini comes with little silver accents and a unique rippling pattern along the waistband.

Today's top videos STORY CONTINUES BELOW  The mum-of-two did a recent Q&A [question and answer] on Instagram, with followers.  Erin McGregor has revealed she will not be opting for a church wedding when she walks down the aisle in 2024. 'Always worth the try' -- Erin McGregor shares realities of travelling with young son 'We want -- Har is our main man,' Terry added. Turning their attention back to the question at hand, Erin asked her husband-to-be what type of music he wanted for their big day.  Erin shared that six-year-old son Harry, who lives with autism, would be more comfortable outdoors, adding that he would be likely to want to leave a church setting. Monty Don is no stranger to muddy boots and gardening gloves, but he left them at home in exchange for much smarter attire as he attended a special family wedding.  The Gardeners' World star, 67, and his wife Sarah were pictured at their son's nuptials back in July 2020 ‚Äì which happened to be their own wedding anniversary. For the occasion, the pair proved their penchant for florals as they stepped out in summery outfits that may have been inspired by their Herefordshire garden, Longmeadow.  WATCH: Monty Don shares personal garden transformation  Monty offset his classic white shirt and black suit with a blue tie covered with yellow flowers, while Sarah tied in with his colour scheme in a stunning pastel blue frock. It featured a high neckline, long sleeves, a ditsy floral print and navy piping which she teamed with pearl drop earrings and her blonde hair in a sleek straight bob.  The celebrity gardener captioned the candid photo, which appears to have been taken at the wedding breakfast: "3 years ago on this day Sarah and I were celebrating our son Adam‚Äôs marriage to Emily. On the same day 37 years ago we were married too."  ¬© Instagram Monty and Sarah's son got married in 2017  At the time, fans rushed to comment on the couple's outfits, writing: "Look at you all poshed up," and: "I love the tie." A third added: "Lucky Monty, Sarah is a beauty."  Monty and Sarah chose much more timeless outfits on their own wedding day. On their 39th anniversary in 2022, he shared one rare throwback photo, taken in 1983, which showed the newlyweds standing outside a set of wrought iron gates, with Monty's new wife rocking an unconventional blue outfit.  Sarah ditched bridal white for a dusty cornflower jacket with large buttons down the front, which she paired with a chunky necklace and matching earrings.  Meanwhile, Monty didn't appear to have aged at all ‚Äì he sported the same thick curly hair and big grin and wore a cream suit and black spotty tie.  He accompanied the photo with a heartfelt message to his childhood sweetheart Sarah, whom he met at Cambridge University. "We got married 39 years ago today - the picture is a little faded, a little wrinkly, like us but the love is as evergreen and strong now as it was all those years ago," Monty sweetly wrote.  Monty and Sarah share three children, Tom, Adam and Freya, and they are proud grandparents to George and Daisy Rose. However, Sarah candidly opened up about her ill health following childbirth and the impact it had on their marriage in their book, The Jewel Garden.  "I was ill for months after our daughter was born despite having had a supposedly film-star birth at an enormously expensive private London hospital," Sarah wrote. "I had a slipped disc, a result of the bodged delivery, and was so anaemic that I needed a blood transfusion.  "My injuries were not acknowledged and as we tried to leave the hospital I had to walk down three flights of stairs because the lift had broken. I was unable to walk or stand properly for over a year," she shared.  Being bedridden put a strain on their relationship, with Sarah candidly writing: "When it came down to it, Montagu was a loony and I was ill all the time." Of all the captivating details of Sofia Richie‚Äôs wedding to Elliot Grainge, her lipstick surprisingly made a lasting impression on me. She donned a pink, peachy shade that was minimal, yet memorable ‚Äì perfectly in line with her understated elegance and effortless personal style.  On her wedding day, Richie told Vogue that she wanted her look to feel timeless. Richie enlisted makeup artist Pati Dubroff, who leaned into subtle enhancements to the star‚Äôs natural beauty. Paired with a glossy gold lid and sunkissed blush, Dubroff accentuated her lips with a sheerness that wasn‚Äôt too saturated. ‚ÄúWe wanted the lips to look fresh and soft, and not have a weighty lipstick feeling. Kissable lips!‚Äù she explains. In the end, this was achieved with a Chanel tinted lip balm accompanied by a natural contour shade lip pencil.  Chanel Rouge Coco Baume Hydrating Beautifying Tinted Lip Balm Buildable Colour ¬£34 at CHANEL  Part of the intrigue of Rouge Coco Baume is how it veils the lips in a practical, buildable colour. As you layer your chosen shade, the finish transforms from a sheer, barely there color to a more opaque and luminous pigment. Richie‚Äôs lip was done with shade 928 Pink Delight, one of nine shades that range from rich reds to iridescent pearls. My personal favorite? 914 Natural Charm, which enhances my pout‚Äôs natural colour.  ‚ÄúThe Rouge Coco Baume range is hydrating and my constant go to!‚Äù Dubroff says, admitting that the formula is perfect for not only summer but in cooler temperatures when lips are more easily chapped. Why? The balm is enriched with a fruit and olive leaf-derived oil that boasts antioxidant and rejuvenation benefits ‚Äì meaning lips are soft, hydrated, and smoother upon application. With its conditioning properties and sheer, never-shiny tint, it‚Äôs safe to say I‚Äôve found my ultimate summer lip.  Below, shop the rest of Sofia Richie‚Äôs bridal beauty look.

The coronation of King Charles III was brimming with historical moments, but the Princess of Wales wearing a custom bejewelled headpiece instead of a tiara was not one I saw coming. There were whispers leading up to the day that Kate would forgo crown jewels at the request of the King because he wanted a more modest ceremony (not sure if we would call this event less opulent, but okay). And veering far from tradition, Kate chose a bespoke leafy-floral headpiece crafted from sequins, metallic beading and sparkling silver threadwork by Jess Collett X Alexander McQueen. It was a royal fashion moment for the books (as was the matching smaller version of the headpiece worn by Princess Charlotte), and one that has tipped off a trend of exquisite and elaborate bejewelled wedding headpieces as coveted accessory.  ‚ÄúI thought Catherine‚Äôs headpiece conveyed a youthful and whimsical vibe,‚Äù says Toronto-based accessory designer Blair Nadeau, founder and owner of Blair Nadeau Bridal Adornments, who is renowned for her exquisite jewellery, veils, hair accessories and crowns. ‚ÄúI literally squealed when I saw it. This accessory didn‚Äôt feel old and stuffy, it felt fresh. I loved the tiered leaf and floral motif and the doubled-banded style. The look is perfect for a wedding because it‚Äôs elegant and impactful and very modern feeling.‚Äù  Nadeau says the organic shape of Kate‚Äôs instantly iconic headpiece is what makes it easy and effortless for brides to wear. ‚ÄúWe are still in a bit of a minimalist era but starting to see the emergence of softer silhouettes and more texture with three-dimensional details like floral embellishments and lace patterns,‚Äù she shares. ‚ÄúThe silver tone provided an airy lightness that is very much happening now with accessories after years of bold gold designs.‚Äù  If you‚Äôre feeling the luxe headpiece vibe for your wedding day, Nadeau has a few thoughts on how to wear them. Pair a design like Kate‚Äôs with a light and airy dress with a fluid silhouette made from tulle, chiffon or lace. She also recommends keeping hair easy and not overly styled. ‚ÄúI actually love the juxtaposition of soft waves with a statement headpiece,‚Äù says Nadeau. ‚ÄúIf you do wear it up, keep it soft and a little imperfect, not too sleek.‚Äù  As for adding other wedding accessories, keep it simple and classic. Kate opted for a pair of diamond and South Sea pearl drop earrings that belonged to Princess Diana, which Nadeau says worked because they complemented the motif of her headpiece. ‚ÄúI actually love a veil combined with a statement headpiece, but the trick is to keep it simple and minimal,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAlways remember your wedding accessories are there to complement you and your dress.‚Äù  Bejewelled wedding headpieces to shop now  This bold trend is here to stay for several wedding seasons  The shape and finish of the Victoria headpiece is very much in step with the Princess of Wales‚Äôs style on Coronation day. It‚Äôs the perfect match for big, bold and volumized hair!  The Arielle headband by Jennifer Behr was first launched in 2010 and continues to be a runaway bestseller. It features hundreds of Swarovski-crystal-adorned leaves fastened to a silver ribbon-wrapped skinny headband.  The Millaray crown features a dramatic criss-cross design that creates a delicate and bold effect. Crafted from crystal beads, enamel and brass flowers, sterling-silver-plated wire and Mokuba silk ribbon, this piece is truly breathtaking.  The Cecilia headband is bedazzling hand-crafted custom piece that can take up to 16 weeks to receive from order date, so plan accordingly. This beauty is hanndmade from rhodium plating and is detailed with fresh water pearls and Swarovski crystals.  The Henri headband mixes pearls and crystals to create a maximum impact wedding accessory. This one would look amazing as a re-wear for any weddings or formal events on your upcoming calendar.  This is an amazing piece of hair jewellery that is very deco-inspired! It wraps around your head and is anchored by two dazzling leaf motifs on either side‚Äîso dramatic and so different!  We love the vintage vibe bow design of this glittering headband by designer Keren Wolf. This halo-style headpiece is easy to wear and pairs beautifully with easy, breezy wedding hair. There are several widely accepted rules for wedding speeches: Don‚Äôt talk about exes. Don‚Äôt dredge up drunken antics. And whatever you do, don‚Äôt wing it.  But a new etiquette question has recently emerged: Can you use AI to write them?  Couples and their loved ones are putting ChatGPT to the emotional Turing test, as they seek to give vows and toasts that are personal and eloquent but don‚Äôt rely on a writerly touch. What they‚Äôre finding is that AI can‚Äôt beat a human on the feelings front‚Äîphew!‚Äîbut it can perhaps help prompt memories or create structure.  Ten days before her wedding, Kelly Tenn, 35, found herself on the planning website Joy, answering prompts from its free AI speechwriting tool, which relies on OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT technology.  ‚ÄúFor me, there‚Äôs obviously this big craze around AI tools over the past few months, and I was a bit skeptical to try to use a tool like this," said Ms. Tenn, a brand-marketing executive for a cloud-technology company in San Francisco. She doesn‚Äôt find writing hard‚Äî‚ÄúI work in content," she said‚Äîbut for vows ‚Äúit takes a little bit more creativity in how you articulate something that is summarizing your relationship over many years and years to come."  Ms. Tenn used the product to create multiple versions of AI-generated vows, including prose ‚Äúspoken like a friend" and ‚ÄúShakespearean-style verbiage" (‚ÄúSo often have I pondered our love and asked, wherefrom hath thy love descended so unexpectedly?"). Ultimately she scrapped the drafts, which she found basic and nondescript, but she said using the tool helped her break out of writer‚Äôs block.  The tool also eased her woes about getting up in front of a crowd on her wedding day. ‚ÄúPublic speaking is not something I prefer to do," Ms. Tenn said. ‚ÄúThis is one of many ways to help lower the barrier and alleviate nerves."  Write Your Own Vows Using AI  Let‚Äôs write vows to an imaginary spouse. Once you answer these questions, the AI tool ChatGPT will generate vows based on your responses.  Ahead of their April wedding, Jeff and Allison Hood of Atlanta used Provenance‚Äôs toast and vow builder, which launched in early 2023. It prompts each partner to share stories, memories and promises for their future spouse. Through the service, which costs $19.99, each partner can also view the relative length and tone of their significant others‚Äô vows without seeing the contents.  ‚ÄúThere was really nothing that didn‚Äôt sound like my authentic voice," said Mr. Hood, 34, a custom clothier. Since he‚Äôs ‚Äúnot a novelist," he was grateful that the tool presented his thoughts in a way that flowed well.  Ms. Hood, 32 and head of growth for a digital-marketing agency, kept a running list in her phone of all the things she loves about her partner since they started dating four years ago. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just like ‚ÄòI stubbed my toe and he brought me a Band-Aid and I felt so special,‚Äô" she said. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt something I could actually say on my wedding day."  Left to her own devices, Ms. Hood said her vows would have sounded as though they had been written by a second-grader: ‚ÄúWill you marry me? Check ‚Äòyes‚Äô or ‚Äòno.‚Äô" Reading what Provenance came up with, she thought, ‚Äú‚ÄòWow, I would have never worded it this way and it sounds so thoughtful‚Äîand the way that I actually feel.‚Äô"  Less than two weeks before giving a rehearsal-dinner toast for a best friend‚Äôs wedding, Randi Kramer, 29, thought: How do I capture nearly a decade of friendship in just a few minutes? Another friend suggested she try ToastWiz, a paid service for crafting speeches that uses AI.  ‚ÄúMore than anything, it was a tool that got me past writer‚Äôs block," said Ms. Kramer, an associate editor at a publishing house in New York City. Thanks to prompts the form gave her‚Äîsuch as asking for adjectives to describe the couple and a favorite anecdote about the bride‚ÄîMs. Kramer was finally able ‚Äúto get the juices flowing."  She paid $30 for three speech drafts. ‚ÄúI was able to Frankenstein it together," she said, estimating that a third of what the chatbot produced made it into her final speech.  ‚ÄúI definitely didn‚Äôt tell anyone," she said, of using the service.  Julia Rosenson, 25, a software engineer in New York City, used Joy‚Äôs service to help write her maid of honor speech for her sister‚Äôs coming September wedding. While she‚Äôs found it to be ‚Äúa fun little tool" to play with, Ms. Rosenson said it should only be used for inspiration.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty hit or miss‚Äîmostly miss‚Äîjust because they don‚Äôt know my sister at all," she said, ‚Äúbut they put together a whole story," adding that it was quite funny to read. ‚ÄúIt generates anecdotes as if I were going to tell a story about my sister and her fianc√© on a camping trip they never took, or some pivotal imaginary relationship moment," Ms. Rosenson said.  Joy‚Äôs CEO Vishal Joshi said the tool‚Äôs invented anecdotes should be seen as placeholders for personal material. ‚ÄúIt will make up interesting stories where it could be like, ‚ÄòOK, a story quote over here would be nice,‚Äô" he said.  Kyle and Sarah Kuo, both 26, of Tempe, Ariz., used Provenance to prepare for their April 2023 wedding. Ms. Kuo, a registered nurse at an outpatient family practice, especially liked the fact that you could cross-check your partner‚Äôs vows to make sure you were on the same page, tone-wise.  ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to put too many jokes in there if your partner is being serious and sentimental," she said.  For his part, Mr. Kuo, a director of operations at a production company, was just glad to have his time back.  ‚ÄúI would have had to Google ‚Äòhow to write your vows‚Äô and read through, you know, nine articles," he said.

Ukrainian troops train to use commercial drones to spot and target enemy forces in Kharkiv Oblast in August. Wolfgang Schwan/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images  In the days after Russia's invasion last year, Ukrainian forces need help targeting Russian troops.  One Ukrainian artillery unit relied on help from Ukrainian civilians to guide their strikes.  Using repurposed drones, cameras and phones, and Google Maps, that unit put rounds on its targets.  Hobby drones and Google Maps were designed to enhance human life, not to end it, but when Russian tank columns seemed to be closing in on Kyiv in the days after Russia's attack on February 24, 2022, desperate Ukrainian defenders found they had two unlikely assets.  Col. Oleh Shevchuk, commander of Ukraine's 43rd Artillery Brigade, and Col. Serhiy Ogerenko, the brigade's chief of staff, told Ukrainian media that they were able to use civilian drones and Google Maps, sometimes with the help of Ukrainian civilians, to locate and target Russian forces in the early days of the war.  At the time, Ukrainian gunners faced the problem of hitting Russian vehicles ‚Äî moving targets ‚Äî without trained forward observers to estimate where the vehicle would be when the shell landed.  "That's why we needed 'eyes,'" Ogerenko said. "We called civilians and asked, 'Do you see this section of the road? If a shell hits in a minute and a half, can you tell us at least roughly where it exploded?' Then the person would describe the place of the explosion, and we would open a Google map and see, yes, there is such a place behind the vegetable gardens."  A woman uses her smartphone in a house damaged by shelling in southeastern Kyiv in March 2022. GENYA SAVILOV/AFP via Getty Images  Civilians also offered to use their hobby drones as scouts and artillery spotters. DJI Mavic quadcopters ‚Äî nicknamed "wedding drones" because that is what they were used to record before the war ‚Äî proved invaluable to the 43rd Artillery Brigade.  "They provided the picture," Shevchuk said, according to a translation of the interview. "4G, WhatsApp, a video call ‚Äî the cameraman picked up, saw something, took off his phone, and said, 'look what I have.' I looked at it and said, 'hold it. We're going to shoot now.' It was convenient."  Story continues  Drones ‚Äî both military-designed and civilian models ‚Äî are among the most vital assets for troops on both sides of the war. Ukrainian and Russian drones prowl the skies constantly, looking for enemy positions and movements, as well as for artillery batteries, supply depots, and command posts.  Shevchuk recounted how "one guy from a gas station even gave us access to his camera." Rather than explain the situation to Ukrainian gunners, the owner told them, "'here's the password. See for yourself,'" Shevchuk recalled. "That's how we saw our first live target ‚Äî a column of Chechens near Novyi Bykiv [37 miles from Kyiv] heading towards Kyiv. So we 'met' them three kilometers [1.9 miles] further."  A drone operator corrects Ukrainian 82mm mortar fire toward Russian positions in the Donetsk region in April. SERGEY SHESTAK/AFP via Getty Images  Sometimes Ukrainian forces would get indications that Russian troops were in a village, but not their precise location. "We open a Google map, see a store, see its phone number, and dial it," said Shevchuk, who described a typical conversation:  "Good evening, we are from Ukraine! Do you have any Katsaps [Ukrainian slur for Russians] in the village?" "Yes." "Where?" "Behind Grandma Hanna's house." "What house does Grandma Hanna have?" "Well, everyone knows her!"  "So you talk to people a little bit and realize where everything is," Shevchuk added.  This isn't the only example of how Ukrainian civil society is using consumer technology to enhance Ukraine's military capabilities. To cope with waves of Russian long-range drones penetrating deep into Ukrainian territory, the Ukrainian military has formed mobile air-defense teams equipped with short-range anti-aircraft weapons.  Ordinary citizens can use cellphone apps to report drone sightings to a central database, which can then alert mobile air-defense units.  Ukrainian troops fire an 2S7 Pion howitzer at Russian positions near Bakhmut in March. Muhammed Enes Yildirim/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images  Ukrainians using video cameras and cellphones to call in artillery fire on Russians forces as they pass by is a bizarre, almost comical, illustration of how a modern war can play out in an urban environment. But it also shows how much danger those civilians faced from invaders intent on defeating Ukraine's military and then repressing the Ukrainian public.  Russian troops and Wagner Group mercenaries have been accused of numerous atrocities against Ukrainian civilians, and Moscow has clamped down on Ukrainians living in areas it still controls in an effort to prevent attacks by partisans or special-operations forces. Anyone suspected of providing intelligence to Ukraine's devastatingly effective artillery could expect little mercy.  "We lost contact with many people, and some said: 'That's it, I'm turning off my phone, deleting all my contacts. There are Russians in the next house,'" Shevchuk said of civilians his forces were in contact with. "Some people immediately said: 'I'm scared, don't ask me any questions.' But people called us from everywhere."  Michael Peck is a defense writer whose work has appeared in Forbes, Defense News, Foreign Policy magazine, and other publications. He holds a master's in political science. Follow him on Twitter and LinkedIn.  Read the original article on Business Insider

Peter Phillips, the only son of Princess Anne and her former husband Mark Phillips, married Canadian-born Autumn Phillips (nee Kelly) on May 17, 2008.  Their ceremony was held at St George‚Äôs Chapel in Windsor Castle, and members of the public flocked to the streets in their thousands to share their well-wishes for the couple. AN invitation to a wedding is a bit of a two-edged sword.  There‚Äôs the compliment of being asked to celebrate the nuptials of friends, making you feel a tiny bit important, or at least, definitely not a c-lister.  The c-listers are relegated to the ‚Äòinsult‚Äô otherwise known as the ‚Äòafters‚Äô where sandwiches are served and you might be offloaded with a slice of wedding cake.  The afters really are something of an after-thought for people that don‚Äôt make the grade but can‚Äôt be completely forgotten about either.  Are they expected to give a gift to the couple? It‚Äôs a bit of a minefield.  Thankfully, most of my friends are not the marrying kind so I haven‚Äôt been encumbered with the diplomatic shenanigans involved in trying to decide on a gift versus cash. I believe cash is king. (There‚Äôs no point in buying a toaster or some other kitchen implement for a couple that will most likely have been living together for years and have everything they need.)  But what is really tricky is the invitation to a destination wedding. It‚Äôs all very well if you decide to get married on a beach in Bali in flip flops and a floaty white dress. But think of the guests.  A couple may find it hard to believe, but travelling for a wedding is often seen as hassle and as expensive.  It requires taking some of your annual leave from work, which you might really resent, having hoped to save your days off to go on a decent holiday of your own choice.  You really may not want to have to rock up somewhere in Italy for a wedding event that, in the old days, used to just take place over the course of a day.  It‚Äôs downright cheeky to assume that your friends and family will welcome a wedding abroad. While close family members have no choice but to follow the couple to a hired villa in France or wherever, friends will be counting the cost.  You‚Äôre talking a few grand (at least ‚Ç¨2,000) which is a big ask for a guest. There‚Äôs all the logistics of getting from the airport to the wedding venue which might be hours away, somewhere deep in the Italian countryside.  Scenic and romantic? Certainly, but far from practical.  Whatever happened to the Saturday wedding in a hotel serving beef or salmon? Now, folk want to emulate celebrities with their fancy notions involving hiring a wedding planner and dragging their mates abroad because ‚Äòit‚Äôs all about the experience‚Äô.  Yes, making memories can be expensive.  But now you have the perfect excuse to decline an invitation to a wedding in some far-flung place. It‚Äôs our old enemy ‚Äì the carbon footprint.  Can you really justify a flight when at least 2.4% of global emissions come from aviation?  Together with other gases and the water vapour trails produced by aircraft, the industry is responsible for around 5% of global warming.  While that may not seem like a massive contributor, only a small percentage of the world flies frequently. It‚Äôs for the relatively rich and indulgent.  Put that on your wedding invitation refusal and you should be off the hook. (On the other hand, if you have plenty of time on your hands, you could indulge in ‚Äòslow travel‚Äô using boats and trains and coaches to get to the celebrations). Now that could be a great and memorable trip. But time may not be on your side.  Most of us are wage slaves unable to dedicate days and days to just travelling to a destination.  According to a BBC report, a return flight from London to San Francisco emits around 5.5 tonnes of CO2 per person, more than twice the emissions produced by a family car in a year and about half of the average carbon footprint of someone living in the UK.  Even a fairly short return flight from London to Berlin emits three times the emissions saved from a year of recycling.  A study involving 29 international students asked them to rate the importance of different flights they had taken. Just 58% of the flights were rated ‚Äòvery important‚Äô or ‚Äòimportant‚Äô.  And really, how important is a flight to the Caribbean for a wedding party?  Unless you‚Äôre close family, you‚Äôd be justified in turning down the invitation ‚Äì on environmental grounds.  Some people compensate for the emissions from their flights by buying a carbon offset. But this is a bit of a cod. Trees, for example, need years to grow enough to reabsorb the carbon from your flight, and there‚Äôs no guarantee they‚Äôll be left standing long enough to counteract your flight emissions.  That kind of thing is for the wealthy who continue contributing to climate change, offsetting, but not changing their behaviour.  The solution to destination weddings? Elope. Just the two of you.

Sophie Taylor, 30, and her partner Shane Burden, 26, moved their wedding forward so Sophie's father could walk her down the aisle.  Carl, 56, was recently diagnosed with stomach cancer which meant the couple had to speed up the timeline.  Sophie, 30, from Stanton Harcourt, and Thames Water employee Shane, 26, from Sutton, and got together at Bartholomew School in Eynsham when Sophie was 13.  The bride recalled: "I‚Äôve been with Shane half my life but we were planning to get married in a few years‚Äô time in Turkey.  "But I recently found out my dad has stomach cancer and his quality of life is gradually getting worse.  "The only thing we both would love is for him to walk me down the aisle, with time not on our side our budget isn‚Äôt the best.  READ ALSO: Potholes make people drive 'like Super Mario'  ‚ÄúHe has just been diagnosed and we are waiting to hear back about his treatment plan or to find out if there is any treatment he can have.  ‚ÄúHis own father died from stomach cancer and he kind of knew even before the doctors told him.‚Äù  She added: ‚ÄúI only actually met my dad five years ago but we have become so close in such a short period of time. He is my absolute rock.  "And having spent so much of my life without him, I just knew I wanted my dad to be there at my wedding.‚Äù  Realising that she had so much to organise in a short time, Sophie appealed for help on community Facebook group Witney Spotted.  She was astounded when she received hundreds offers of help or advice.  The Brewers‚Äô Tap offered to provide a bar free of charge, a ribboned wedding car was offered by Townhouse Executive Travel Limited, whroadshows offered to do the disco for free, Ozzy James Photography offered free wedding photography, event planner Christina Hopkinson offered to help for free, Sophie Zandra offered beauty treatments and Make Up by Mariella offered free wedding make-up and hair.  Singer Ann-Marie Warner posted: "So sorry that your family are experiencing such heartache. I would be happy to provide some live entertainment around your DJ. I can also sing your first dance song if it‚Äôs something in my range. X"  Kibble Property Services said they could share contacts for hall, disco, catering and possibly all decorations.  Billy Branford-Parsons said: "I have tons of tableware from our wedding which you would be very welcome to use if it would be useful - tablecloths, napkins, vintage cutlery and vintage mismatched cups and saucers for around 100 people."  Multiple wedding dresses were offered in varying sizes.  Sophie said: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt keep up with the offers. It's been so overwhelming.  ‚ÄúThe hardest part was going to be finding a venue at such short notice particularly with summer coming and that was why I reached out.  "But I was blown away by the response.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been in touch with a couple of people who have offered wedding dresses and I have a friend who works in Blossom Bridal in Witney and I‚Äôm going to try some on to get the size and the style and then I will be looking at second hand offers and in Barnado‚Äôs.‚Äù  At the moment the likely venue is Witney‚Äôs Corn Exchange for a date around September 16.  READ ALSO: Witney teen arrested for assault and possession of a knife  ‚ÄúLike most people I was looking forward to a big day since childhood and now that‚Äôs even more important as we want to make lasting memories," she said.  There are 77 people on the guest list including family and the couple‚Äôs son Liam, nine, who will page boy and their two daughters, Sienna, five, and Sophia, one, who will be flower girls.  Sophie will also have her sister and best friend as bridesmaids.  She added: "Thank you all so much I‚Äôm still getting round to messaging people it‚Äôs all gone a little bit crazy!  "I‚Äôm completely overwhelmed with the amazing generosity of people and feel blessed to live in such a great community."  So how does she think she will feel on what should be her happiest day.  ‚ÄúDad‚Äôs obviously very excited for me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs going to be a very emotional day.‚Äù
